classFeature.name: Magical Tinkering
entries: At 1st level, you learn how to invest a spark of magic into mundane objects. When you craft a mundane object, you do so spending only half of its required material cost and half the time needed to craft it.

In addition, you can combine some of your magic within mundane objects, allowing you to turn them into minor magical items. With one hour of work, or when you finish a short or long rest, you can transform a number of nonmagical objects that aren't armor, weapons, or a shield, equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) into a Tinkered Object, granting them a Tinker Mod you know. You can do so once per long rest. If you spend gold to turn an object into a permanent Tinkered Object (the cost of which is detailed in the Tinker Mod), you can do so with no limit. An object can only hold 1 Tinker Mod at a time, and it loses the Tinker Mod if you attempt to add a different Tinker Mod to it, or if you die. A dispel magic spell can also dismiss the effects of the Tinker Mod, requiring 10 minutes, or spending a 1st-level or higher spell slot to reapply the lost magic.

A Tinker Mod is a small magical modification that can add to the versatility and power of an object. These are often the beginnings to your magical inventions to come. A Tinkered Object can also be used as an arcane focus for your artificer spells, provided it can fit in one hand and can be carried. Some Tinker Mods require specific requirements to apply and learn them. If you lose one of these requirements over your adventure for one of your known Tinker Mods, you lose the ability to grant the mod to an object, but not the knowledge of the Tinker Mod itself.

You have one known Tinker Mod and you learn more Tinker Mods as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Artificer Table. You can replace a Tinker Mod you know for another one that you qualify for each time you gain a level in this class. If any objects were granted a Tinker Mod that you have replaced for another one, they lose the mod. If a Tinker Mod requires a saving throw, it uses your Artificer Spell Save DC.

entries.name: Artificer Tinker Mods
entries: In the world of Torin, it is widely known about how temporary a Tinkered Object can potentially be, with it requiring its creator staying alive. It is not recommended to sell these objects to NPCs, but if such a thing is required, they should not be sold for any more than 10 gp.

Most commoners will be disinterested in Tinkered Objects for lack of an understanding of what they are and how they work exactly, thus they will often be suspicious of the validity of an artificer's claims, especially if the given object looks confusing or too mundane.
Unless a Tinker Mod's description says otherwise, you can't learn an infusion more than once.

classFeature.name: Optional Rule: Firearm Proficiency
entries: The secrets of creating and operating gunpowder weapons have been discovered in various corners of the D&D multiverse. If your Dungeon Master uses the rules on firearms in {@book chapter 9|DMG|9|Firearms} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} and your artificer has been exposed to the operation of such weapons, your artificer is proficient with them.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have studied the workings of magic and how to channel it through objects. As a result, you have gained the ability to cast spells. To observers, you don't appear to be casting spells in a conventional way; you look as if you're producing wonders using mundane items or outlandish inventions.

entries.name: Tools Required
entries: You produce your artificer spell effects through your tools. You must have a spellcasting focusspecifically {@item thieves' tools|phb} or some kind of {@item artisan's tools|phb|artisan's tool}in hand when you cast any spell with this Spellcasting feature (meaning the spell has an 'M' component when you cast it). You must be proficient with the tool to use it in this way. See {@book chapter 5|PHB|4}, "Equipment," in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} for descriptions of these tools.
After you gain the Infuse Item feature at 2nd level, you can also use any item bearing one of your infusions as a spellcasting focus.

entries.name: The Magic of Artifice
entries: As an artificer, you use tools when you cast your spells. When describing your spellcasting, think about how you're using a tool to perform the spell effect. If you cast {@spell cure wounds} using {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB}, you could be quickly producing a salve. If you cast it using {@item tinker's tools|PHB}, you might have a miniature mechanical spider that binds wounds. When you cast {@spell poison spray}, you could fling foul chemicals or use a wand that spits venom. The effect of the spell is the same as for a spellcaster of any other class, but your method of spellcasting is special.

The same principle applies when you prepare your spells. As an artificer, you don't study a spellbook or pray to prepare your spells. Instead, you work with your tools and create the specialized items you'll use to produce your effects. If you replace {@spell cure wounds} with {@spell heat metal}, you might be altering the device you use to healperhaps modifying a tool so that it channels heat instead of healing energy.

Such details don't limit you in any way or provide you with any benefit beyond the spell's effects. You don't have to justify how you're using tools to cast a spell. But describing your spellcasting creatively is a fun way to distinguish yourself from other spellcasters.

entries.name: Cantrips (0-Level Spells)
entries: At 1st level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the {@filter artificer spell list|spells|level=0|class=Artificer}. At higher levels, you learn additional artificer cantrips of your choice, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Artificer table.
When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the artificer cantrips you know with another cantrip from the artificer spell list.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Artificer table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your artificer spells. To cast one of your artificer spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of artificer spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the {@filter artificer spell list|spells|class=Artificer}. When you do so, choose a number of artificer spells equal to your Intelligence modifier + half your artificer level, rounded down (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

For example, if you are a 5th-level artificer, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With an Intelligence of 14, your list of prepared spells can include four spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination. If you prepare the 1st-level spell {@spell cure wounds}, you can cast it using a 1st-level or a 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of artificer spells requires time spent tinkering with your spellcasting focuses: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your artificer spells; your understanding of the theory behind magic allows you to wield these spells with superior skill. You use your Intelligence whenever an artificer spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for an artificer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast an artificer spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared.

classFeature.name: Infuse Item
entries: At 2nd level, you gain the ability to imbue mundane items with certain magical infusions. The magic items you create with this feature are effectively prototypes of permanent items.

entries.name: Artificer Infusions
entries: Artificers have invented numerous magical infusions, extraordinary processes that rapidly create magic items. To many, artificers seem like wonderworkers, accomplishing in hours what others need weeks to complete.
The description of each of the following infusions details the type of item that can receive it, along with whether the resulting magic item requires attunement.
Some infusions specify a minimum artificer level. You can't learn such an infusion until you are at least that level.
Unless an infusion's description says otherwise, you can't learn an infusion more than once.

entries.name: Infusing an Item
entries: Whenever you finish a long rest, you can touch a nonmagical object and imbue it with one of your artificer infusions, turning it into a magic item. An infusion works on only certain kinds of objects, as specified in the infusion's description. If the item requires attunement, you can attune yourself to it the instant you infuse the item. If you decide to attune to the item later, you must do so using the normal process for attunement. (see "Attunement" in chapter 7 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

Your infusion remains in an item indefinitely, but when you die, the infusion vanishes after a number of days have passed equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1 day). The infusion also vanishes if you give up your knowledge of the infusion for another one.

You can infuse more than one nonmagical object at the end of a long rest; the maximum of which is equal to your proficiency bonus. You must touch each of the objects, and each of your infusions can be in only one object at a time. Moreover, no object can bear more than one of your infusions at a time. If you try to exceed your maximum number of infusions, the oldest infusion immediately ends, and then the new infusion applies. Only you can use these infused items.

entries.name: Infusing an Ally's Item
entries: You can make additional infusions for your allies. When you finish a long rest, you can infuse objects for a number of creatures up to 2 plus your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 3), following the same rules for infusing an item, but with the following changes:

items: An ally can only have 1 infused object. At 10th level, they can have 2 infused objects.
That ally is the only creature who can use the infused item.
If the infused item is more than 100 feet away from the ally or yourself for longer than 1 hour, it loses the infusion.

entries.name: Ending an Infusion
entries: An artificer can automatically end one of its infusions as a bonus action. If an infusion ends on an item that contains other things, like a bag of holding, its contents harmlessly appear in and around its space.

classFeature.name: Infusions Known
entries: You know a number of {@filter Artificer Infusions|optionalfeatures|feature type=ai|source=TACS} equal to twice your proficiency bonus, choosing four when you gain this feature, and learning additional infusions when your proficiency bonus increases.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the artificer infusions you learned with a new one.

classFeature.name: Artificer Specialist
entries: At 3rd level, you choose the type of specialist you are, each of which is detailed at the end of the class's description. Your choice grants you features at 5th level and again at 9th and 15th level.

classFeature.name: The Right Tool for the Job
entries: At 3rd level, you learn how to produce exactly the tool you need: with {@item thieves' tools|PHB} or {@item artisan's tools|PHB} in hand, you can magically create one set of {@item artisan's tools|PHB} in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you. This creation requires 1 hour of uninterrupted work, which can coincide with a short or long rest. Though the product of magic, the tools are nonmagical, and they vanish when you use this feature again.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Artificer Specialist Feature
entries: At 5th level, you gain a feature granted by your Artificer Specialist choice.

classFeature.name: Tool Expertise
entries: Starting at 6th level, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses your proficiency with a tool.

classFeature.name: Flash of Genius
entries: Starting at 7th level, you gain the ability to come up with solutions under pressure. When you or another creature you can see within 30 feet of you makes an ability check or a saving throw, you can use your reaction to add your Intelligence modifier to the roll.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Artificer Specialist Feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature granted by your Artificer Specialist choice.

classFeature.name: Magic Item Adept
entries: When you reach 10th level, you achieve a profound understanding of how to use and make magic items:

items: You can attune to up to four magic items at once.
If you craft a magic item with a rarity of common or uncommon, it takes you a quarter of the normal time, and it costs you half as much of the usual gold.
When you use your infuse item feature, you can choose to infuse magic items, provided they are not weapons or armor. You can still infuse a shield using this feature.

classFeature.name: Spell-Storing Item
entries: At 11th level, you learn how to store a spell in an object. Whenever you finish a long rest, you can touch one {@filter simple or martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon;simple weapon} or one item that you can use as a spellcasting focus, and you store a spell in it, choosing a 1st- or 2nd-level spell from the {@filter artificer spell list|spells|class=Artificer|cast time=action|level=1;2} that requires 1 action to cast (you needn't have it prepared).

While holding the object, a creature can take an action to produce the spell's effect from it, using your spellcasting ability modifier. If the spell requires concentration, the creature must concentrate. The spell stays in the object until it's been used a number of times equal to twice your Intelligence modifier (minimum of twice) or until you use this feature again to store a spell in an object.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Magic Item Savant
entries: At 14th level, your skill with magic items deepens more:

items: You can attune to up to five magic items at once.
You ignore all class, race, spell, and level requirements on attuning to or using a magic item.
If you craft a magic item with a rarity of rare, it takes you half the normal time.
When you use your infuse item feature, you can choose to infuse magic armor.

classFeature.name: Artificer Specialist Feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted by your Artificer Specialist choice.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Magic Item Master
entries: Starting at 18th level, you've mastered the art of magical craftsmanship:

items: You can attune to up to six magic items at once.
If you craft a magic item with a rarity of very rare, it takes you half the normal time.
When you use your infuse item feature, you can choose to infuse magic weapons.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Mastery of Artifice
entries: At 20th level, you develop a mystical connection to your magic items, which allows you to control them at will:

items: If you're reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can use your reaction to end one of your artificer infusions, causing you to drop to 1 hit point instead of 0.
You can use a bonus action and expend a 1st-level or higher spell slot to choose an item you have infused and immediately swap the infusion for another one you know.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: Born with an innate ability to manipulate the weave and the magic that follows, you can cast spells and bend fate to your whim. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} of the Player's Handbook for the general rules of Spellcasting.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know three cantrips of your choice from the {@filter fate weaver spell list|spells|class=fate weaver (FW)}. You learn an additional fate weaver cantrip of your choice at 4th level and another at 10th level.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Fate Weaver table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your fate weaver spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these fate weaver spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of fate weaver spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the {@filter fate weaver spell list|spells|class=Fate Weaver (FW)}. When you do so, choose a number of fate weaver spells equal to your Charisma modifier + your fate weaver level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

For example, if you are a 3rd-level Fate Weaver, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With a Charisma of 16, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination. If you prepare the 1st-level spell cure wounds, you can cast it using a 1st-level or 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of Fate Weaver spells requires time spent in prayer and medidation: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your fate weaver spells, so you use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a fate weaver spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast a Fate Weaver spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item Divination Focus|TACS} (found above) as a spellcasting focus for your Fate Weaver spells.

classFeature.name: Aspect of Fate
entries: Each Fate Weaver chosen by the Goddess of Magic is granted a certain aspect that can change the course of battle. Each of the various Aspects of Fate are loosely inspired by tarot cards and the infamous {@item Deck of Many Things|dmg}.

classFeature.name: Fate Weaving
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you have the ability to bend fate around you. You have a pool of dice that you can use to grant you or your allies the ability to avoid danger. You have two fate dice, and gain an additional fate die as shown on the table for your level. Each fate die is a d4. You can use your reaction to spend one of these fate dice and use one of the following effects:

items: Choose a creature within 30 ft of you, that creature can roll the fate die and add the result to one ability check, attack roll, or saving throw they made. This can be done before or after knowing the result, but before the outcome is determined.
When an enemy would hit you or a creature within 30ft of you with an attack roll, you can roll the fate die and subtract the result from the attack, potentially changing the outcome.

Choose a creature within 30 ft of you, that creature can roll the fate die and add the result as temporary hit points. These temporary hit points can stack with other instances of temporary hit points, but are always subtracted first.

entries: You regain spent fate dice after a long rest. At higher levels your fate dice increase in size, becoming a d6 at 5th level, a d8 at 10th, a d10 at 15th, and a d12 at 20th.

classFeature.name: Boon of Fate
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you gain the ability to change the fates of those around you. As an action on your turn by spending a 1st level spell slot you can give a willing creature within 15 ft of you a Boon of Fate for one hour. Whenever a creature with a Boon of Fate makes an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, they can spend their Boon of Fate to roll an additional d20 and choose the highest or lowest result of their choice.
When you gain higher level spell slots, you can expend those to give a number of creatures equal to the spell slot's level a Boon of Fate. A creature can only have one Boon of Fate at a time.
You have a number of uses of this feature equal to your proficiency bonus, and regain all expended uses after a long rest.

classFeature.name: Divination Dice
entries: Starting at 5th level, you gain the ability to predict the future of events, or maybe even manipulate them in certain instances of time. Whenever you complete a long rest you roll two d6s and record the numbers rolled. You can then make these foretelling dice weal or woe dice. You can use these dice to modify the end result of an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw of a creature you can see, applying a negative modifier with woe dice or a positive modifier with weal dice. No action is required to use these dice, but you must choose to use them before the roll is made

Each foretelling roll can be used only once, and the maximum number of dice that can be weal or woe is equal to half your proficiency bonus (rounded down). When you finish a long rest, you lose any unused foretelling rolls.
When you reach 11th level the amount of dice you roll increases to three and at 17th level it increases to four.

classFeature.name: Spell Weaving
entries: Some were born with magic, some were born to have magic, some were born to master magic, the Fate Weaver was born with all of these traits. Starting at 3rd level, you gain the uncanny ability to manipulate the spell slots that you possess. As a bonus action, by expending a spell slot of 2nd level or higher you can convert that spell slot into a number of lower level spell slots equal to the spell slot's level. You can distribute the spell slots as you wish.

Alternatively you can convert two spell slots of 8th level or lower into a higher level spell. For example, you can take two 1st level spell slots to make one 2nd level, or one 2nd level and one 1st level to make one 3rd level spell slot. You cannot create a spell slot level higher than your highest level spell slot.
You cannot create more spell slots than the maximum amount you can normally possess.
You have a number of uses of this feature equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses after a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Aspect of Fate Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Aspect of Fate.

classFeature.name: Revelation (3rd level)
entries: Upon reaching 7th level, you can choose a 3rd level spell from the school of magic you chose at 3rd level. It counts as a fate weaver spell for you and you can cast the spell once, regaining the ability to do so again when you finish a long rest. You cannot cast this spell using your spell slots.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Aspect of Fate Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Aspect of Fate.

classFeature.name: Revelation
entries: As a manipulator of fate and magic, you have dreams of the past, present, and futures which reveal to you various magical secrets. When you reach 3rd level, choose from one of the schools of magic, then choose a 1st and a 2nd level spell from the chosen school of magic. The spell does not have to be from the fate weaver spellcasting list. When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the spells chosen from this revelation that is of the same level and from the same school of magic. You can replace your chosen school of magic for these revelations when you gain an ability score improvement in this class, replacing all of your spells accordingly.

The chosen spells count as fate weaver spells for you and you can cast them once each without expending a spell slot, regaining the ability to cast that spell again in the same way when you finish a long rest. You cannot cast these spells using your spell slots. You do not require material components when you cast the spell, unless it is specified in the spell's description.
You receive more revelations when you reach certain levels in this class, gaining one at 7th level, another at 11th level, and a final one at 15th level.

classFeature.name: Revelation (4th level)
entries: Upon reaching 11th level, you can choose a 4th level spell from the school of magic you chose at 3rd level. It counts as a fate weaver spell for you and you can cast the spell once, regaining the ability to do so again when you finish a long rest. You cannot cast this spell using your spell slots.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Aspect of Fate Feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Aspect of Fate.

classFeature.name: Revelation (5th level)
entries: Upon reaching 15th level, you can choose a 5th level spell from the school of magic you chose at 3rd level. It counts as a fate weaver spell for you and you can cast the spell once, regaining the ability to do so again when you finish a long rest. You cannot cast this spell using your spell slots.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Aspect of Fate Feature
entries: At 18th level, you gain a feature granted by your Aspect of Fate.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Boon of the Weave
entries: At 20th level, you have become the right hand of the Goddess of Magic. Your ability to manipulate the weave and call upon it is unrivaled, gaining the power to alter the very fabric of reality.
You've gained the ability to warp time and reality around you. By spending 8 fate dice, choose one of the following effects:

items.name: Alter Reality
entries: As an action, choose any one event from the previous 24 hours. By the DM's discretion, you can alter specifications of the event, changing failures to success and vice versa. If the event includes an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you can treat that roll as the maximum possible result or the minimum possible result, treating any damage or healing that would come thereafter accordingly.

You can alter reality in various ways outside of the provided format above, one example being replacing a player character's position with that of another player or NPC. The DM has the final say over what can or cannot be done depending on your campaign.

items.name: Fateful Wish
entries: As an action, you can duplicate any 7th level or lower spell, You don't need to meet any requirements in that spell, including costly components. The spell simply takes effect. For the purposes of determining the spell's level, it is treated as an 8th level spell.

items.name: Restoration of the Weave
entries: Roll all of the expended fate dice and add your Charisma modifier to the roll, you and each creature within 30 feet of you regain hit points equal to the total.

Altering reality takes a huge toll on your body and mind as altering the fabric of reality has its downsides. If you used the Alter Reality' function of this ability, when next you complete a short or long rest, you receive the stress a {@spell Wish} spell would provide if you were to do anything other than duplicate a spell.
Otherwise, you instead suffer a level of exhaustion that can only be restored after a long rest.
Once you have used one of these effects, you cannot use another effect until you have completed a long rest or, if you suffered the stress of this ability, until your stress has recovered.

classFeature.name: Draconic Origin
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you have draconic blood running through your veins as part of your draconic inheritance. You gain the following benefits:
You learn how to speak, read, and write draconic. If you already have draconic from another source, you can choose one other language.

Choose either chromatic, gem, or metallic, then choose from either black, blue, green, red, or white for chromatic. Brass, bronze, copper, gold, or silver for metallic. These determine your draconic origin, what type of dragon is responsible for your powers, and what type of scales riddle your body.
Depending on your choice, you gain resistance to a specific damage type.
If you choose metallic, you gain proficiency in your choice of either an artisan's tool or a musical instrument.
If you choose chromatic, you gain proficiency in one of the following skills: deception, intimidation, performance, or persuasion.
If you choose gem, you can speak, read, and write in one other language of your choosing from the common or exotic languages.

classFeature.name: Draconic Powers
entries: Also at 1st level you learn the ancient secrets of dragons. You gain additional powers as shown in the Draconic Powers column in the Dragon Warrior Table.

classFeature.name: Draconic Archetype
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature granted by your Draconic Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Starting at fifth level, when you take the attack action on your turn you can make an additional weapon attack.

classFeature.name: Draconic Archetype Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted by your Draconic Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Draconic Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Draconic Archetype Feature
entries: At 17th level, you gain a feature granted by your Draconic Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Draconic Archetype Feature
entries: At 20th level, you gain a feature granted by your Draconic Archetype.

At 1st level, choose two of your skill proficiencies, or one of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with {@item thieves' tools|phb}). Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
At 9th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with {@item thieves' tools|phb}) to gain this benefit.
classFeature.name: Expertise
Sneak Attack
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe's distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.
You don't need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn't {@condition incapacitated}, and you don't have disadvantage on the attack roll.
The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue table.

If you were hidden from the target, or if the target was surprised, the extra damage from your sneak attack increases by {@dice 1d6}. This bonus becomes {@dice 2d8} at 7th level and {@dice 3d10} at 13th level.

classFeature.name: Thieves' Cant
entries: During your rogue training you learned thieves' cant, a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. Only another creature that knows thieves' cant understands such messages. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.

In addition, you understand a set of secret signs and symbols used to convey short, simple messages, such as whether an area is dangerous or the territory of a thieves' guild, whether loot is nearby, or whether the people in an area are easy marks or will provide a safe house for thieves on the run.

classFeature.name: Cunning Action
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take a bonus action on each of your turns in combat. This action can be used only to take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide} action.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype
entries: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you emulate in the exercise of your rogue abilities from the list of available archetypes. Your archetype choice grants you features at 3rd level and then again at 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

classFeature.name: Steady Aim
entries: {@i 3rd-level rogue {@variantrule optional class features|TACS|optional feature}}

As a bonus action, you give yourself advantage on your next attack roll on the current turn. You can use this bonus action only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you use the bonus action, your speed is 0 until the end of the current turn.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: Starting at 5th level, when an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack's damage against you.

classFeature.name: Improved Critical
entries: Beginning at 5th level, your training with weapons requiring particularly steady and precise attacks makes you adept at pinpointing weak points that you can further exploit. If you meet the requirements for your sneak attack feature, the first attack you make on your turn with a finesse or ranged weapon scores a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.
At higher levels, this critical threshold increases, allowing you to score a critical hit on a roll of 18-20 at 9th level, 17-20 at 13th level, 16-20 at 14th level, and 15-20 at 20th level.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: Beginning at 7th level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as a red dragon's fiery breath or an {@spell ice storm} spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail, provided you are not {@condition incapacitated}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: At 9th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with {@item thieves' tools|phb}) to gain the benefit of Expertise.

classFeature.name: Improved Critical (18-20)
entries: Your critical threshold range increases to 18-20.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Reliable Talent
entries: By 11th level, you have refined your chosen skills until they approach perfection. Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a {@dice d20} roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Improved Critical (17-20)
entries: Your critical threshold range increases to 17-20.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype feature
entries: at 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Improved Critical (16-20)
entries: Your critical threshold range increases to 16-20.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Stroke of Luck
entries: At 20th level, you have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. If your attack misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the {@dice d20} roll as a 20.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

classFeature.name: Improved Critical (15-20)
entries: Your critical threshold range increases to 15-20.

classFeature.name: Arcane Recovery
entries: You have learned to regain some of your magical energy by studying your spellbook. Once per day when you finish a short rest, you can choose expended spell slots to recover. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than half your wizard level (rounded up), and none of the slots can be 6th level or higher.
For example, if you're a 4th-level wizard, you can recover up to two levels worth of spell slots.
You can recover either a 2nd-level spell slot or two 1st-level spell slots.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: As a student of arcane magic, you have a spellbook containing spells that show the first glimmerings of your true power. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|PHB|11} for the {@filter wizard spell list|spells|class=wizard}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know three cantrips of your choice from the wizard spell list. You learn additional wizard cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Wizard table.

entries.name: Spellbook
entries: At 1st level, you have a spellbook containing four 1st-level {@filter wizard spells|spells|class=wizard} of your choice. Your spellbook is the repository of the wizard spells you have learned. A spellbook isn't required to cast spells, it is merely a conduit that can be supplemented by any other magic device. The knowledge of the spells within the spellbook are fixed into your mind. You can use your spellbook to help guide yourself or other wizards into learning new spells. Each time you gain a wizard level, up until after 9th level, you can add two wizard spells of your choice to your spellbook. After 9th level, you add 1 spell for each wizard level. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots, as shown on the Wizard table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Wizard table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your wizard spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your wizard spells, since you learn your wizard spells through dedicated study and memorization. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a wizard spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast a wizard spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell in your spellbook.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} or your {@item spellbook|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your wizard spells.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition
entries: When you reach 2nd level, you choose an arcane tradition from the list of available traditions, shaping your practice of magic. Your choice grants you features at 2nd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

classFeature.name: Cantrip Formulas
entries: {@i 3rd-level wizard {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}

You have scribed a set of arcane formulas in your spellbook that you can use to formulate a cantrip in your mind. Whenever you finish a long rest and consult those formulas in your spellbook, you can replace one wizard cantrip you know with another cantrip from the wizard spell list.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Spell Scriber
entries: Starting at 5th level, the time and gold it takes to make a spell discovery check is halved for you. In addition, you are adept at crafting spell scrolls. The gold and time you must spend to make spell scrolls is halved.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Arcane Tradition.

classFeature.name: Arcane Studies
entries: Starting at 7th level, you've learned how to incorporate your own knowledge of magic and utilize it into casting spells from other classes in your own unique way. Choose one spell not on the wizard spell list of 1st or 2nd level. You learn the chosen spell, but it doesn't count against the number of wizard spells you know. You add the chosen spell into your spellbook, but other wizards cannot learn that spell unless they do so through this feature.
You learn another spell in this way at 11th level, the maximum level of which can be 4th, and you learn one last spell in this way at 15th level, the maximum level of which can be 6th.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Arcane Tradition.

classFeature.name: Arcane Studies (x2)
entries: At 11th level, you learn another spell from any spell list, the maximum level of which can be 4th.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Arcane Tradition.

classFeature.name: Arcane Studies (x3)
entries: At 15th level, you learn another spell from any spell list, the maximum level of which can be 6th.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Spell Mastery
entries: At 18th level, you have achieved such mastery over certain spells that you can cast them at will. Choose a 1st-level wizard spell and a 2nd-level wizard spell that are in your spellbook. You can cast those spells at their lowest level without expending a spell slot. If you want to cast either spell at a higher level, you must expend a spell slot as normal.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Signature Spells
entries: When you reach 20th level, you gain mastery over two powerful spells and can cast them with little effort. Choose two 3rd-level wizard spells in your spellbook as your signature spells. You can cast each of them once at 3rd level without expending a spell slot. When you do so, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.
If you want to cast either spell at a higher level, you must expend a spell slot as normal.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron
entries: At 1st level, you have struck a bargain with an otherworldly being chosen from the list of available patrons. Your choice grants you features at 1st level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

classFeature.name: Pact Magic
entries: Your arcane research and the magic bestowed on you by your patron have given you facility with spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|PHB|11} for the {@filter warlock spell list|spells|class=warlock}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know two cantrips of your choice from the warlock spell list. You learn additional warlock cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Warlock table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Warlock table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter warlock spells|spells|class=warlock} of 1st through 5th level. The table also shows what the level of those slots is; all of your spell slots are the same level. To cast one of your warlock spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a spell slot. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a short or long rest.
For example, when you are 5th level, you have two 3rd-level spell slots. To cast the 1st-level spell {@spell witch bolt}, you must spend one of those slots, and you cast it as a 3rd-level spell.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: At 1st level, you know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the warlock spell list.

The Spells Known column of the Warlock table shows when you learn more warlock spells of your choice of 1st level and higher. A spell you choose must be of a level no higher than what's shown in the table's Slot Level column for your level. When you reach 6th level, for example, you learn a new warlock spell, which can be 1st, 2nd, or 3rd level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the warlock spells you know and replace it with another spell from the warlock spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your warlock spells, so you use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a warlock spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your warlock spells.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Invocations
entries: In your study of occult lore, you have unearthed eldritch invocations, fragments of forbidden knowledge that imbue you with an abiding magical ability.

At 2nd level, you gain two eldritch invocations of your choice. A list of the available options can be found on the {@filter Optional Features|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=EI} page. When you gain certain warlock levels, you gain additional invocations of your choice, as shown in the Invocations Known column of the Warlock table.
Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the invocations you know and replace it with another invocation that you could learn at that level.

If an eldritch invocation has prerequisites, you must meet them to learn it. You can learn the invocation at the same time that you meet its prerequisites. A level prerequisite refers to your level in this class.

classFeature.name: Pact Boon
entries: At 3rd level, your otherworldly patron bestows a gift upon you for your loyal service. You gain one of the following features of your choice.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level warlock {@variantrule optional class features|TACS|optional feature}}
Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can do one of the following, representing a change of focus in your occult studies:

items: Replace one cantrip you learned from this class's Pact Magic feature with another cantrip from the {@filter warlock spell list|spells|level=0|class=Warlock}.
Replace the option you chose for the Pact Boon feature with one of that feature's other options.
If you're 12th level or higher, replace one spell from your Mystic Arcanum feature with another warlock spell of the same level.

entries: If this change makes you ineligible for any of your Eldritch Invocations, you must also replace them now, choosing invocations for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Sanity
entries: At 5th level, you can empower your mind temporarily by calling upon your patron's power. While you are charmed or frightened, you can use your action to end the effects, even if your action would have otherwise been unavailable due to being charmed or frightened. If you do not have an action unrelated to those two conditions, you cannot use your action to end those conditions.
Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Otherworldly Patron.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Lore
entries: When you reach 7th level, you gain proficiency in two skills of your choice from the list of skills available to warlocks at 1st level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Bargain
entries: Starting at 9th level, you can expend 5 hit dice as a bonus action to regain an expended warlock spell slot. You can use this feature once, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest. You can use this feature a second time before needing to finish a long rest when you reach 13th level, and a third time when you reach 17th level.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Otherworldly Patron.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum (6th level)
entries: At 11th level, your patron bestows upon you a magical secret called an arcanum. Choose one {@filter 6th-level spell from the warlock spell list|spells|level=6|class=Warlock} as this arcanum.
You can cast your arcanum spell once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

At higher levels, you gain more warlock spells of your choice that can be cast in this way: one 7th-level spell at 13th level, one 8th-level spell at 15th level, and one 9th-level spell at 17th level. You regain all uses of your Mystic Arcanum when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum (7th level)
entries: At 13th level, your patron bestows upon you a magical secret called an arcanum. Choose one {@filter 7th-level spell from the warlock spell list|spells|level=7|class=Warlock} as this arcanum.
You can cast your arcanum spell once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Otherworldly Patron.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum (8th level)
entries: At 15th level, your patron bestows upon you a magical secret called an arcanum. Choose one {@filter 8th-level spell from the warlock spell list|spells|level=8|class=Warlock} as this arcanum.
You can cast your arcanum spell once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum (9th level)
entries: At 17th level, your patron bestows upon you a magical secret called an arcanum. Choose one {@filter 9th-level spell from the warlock spell list|spells|level=9|class=Warlock} as this arcanum.
You can cast your arcanum spell once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Presence
entries: At 18th level, you've grown to be an exceptionally powerful being after selling yourself to the service of another greatly powerful being, to the point where your very presence is imposing against others.

As an action, you can force a creature within 60 feet of you that can see you to make a Wisdom saving throw against your warlock spell save DC. On a failed save, they become overwhelmed by your presence, causing them to be {@condition incapacitated} until the start of your next turn. Afterwhich, you have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks for the next hour. A creature is immune to this ability if they are immune to being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Master
entries: At 20th level, you can draw on your inner reserve of mystical power while entreating your patron to regain expended spell slots. You can spend 1 minute entreating your patron for aid to regain all your expended spell slots from your Pact Magic feature. Once you regain spell slots with this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin
entries: Choose a sorcerous origin, which describes the source of your innate magical power, from the list of available origins.
Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level and again at 6th, 14th, and 18th level.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: An event in your past, or in the life of a parent or ancestor, left an indelible mark on you, infusing you with arcane magic. This font of magic, whatever its origin, fuels your spells. See {@book chapter 10|phb|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|phb|11} for the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|class=sorcerer}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know four cantrips of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. You learn an additional sorcerer cantrip of your choice at 4th level and another at 10th level.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Sorcerer table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter sorcerer spells|spells|class=sorcerer} of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these sorcerer spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell burning hands} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell burning hands} using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the sorcerer spell list.

You learn an additional sorcerer spell of your choice at each level except 12th, 14th, 16th, 18th, 19th, and 20th. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 3rd level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the sorcerer spells you know and replace it with another spell from the sorcerer spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells, since the power of your magic relies on your ability to project your will into the world. You use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a sorcerer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Innate Magic
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells, however you do not require one to cast spells which require a material component that does not have a specified cost or is consumed.

classFeature.name: Sorcery
entries: At 2nd level, you tap into a deep wellspring of magic within yourself. This wellspring is represented by sorcery points, which allow you to create a variety of magical effects.

classFeature.name: Flexible Casting
entries: You can use your sorcery points to gain additional spell slots, or sacrifice spell slots to gain additional sorcery points. You learn other ways to use your sorcery points as you reach higher levels.

entries.name: Creating Spell Slots
entries: You can transform unexpended sorcery points into one spell slot as a bonus action on your turn. The created spell slots vanish at the end of a long rest. The Creating Spell Slots table shows the cost of creating a spell slot of a given level. You can create spell slots no higher in level than 5th. You can create spell slots using your sorcery points a number of times per day equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Converting a Spell Slot to Sorcery Points
entries: As a bonus action on your turn, you can expend one spell slot and gain a number of sorcery points equal to the amount it would cost to make a slot of that level.

classFeature.name: Sorcery Points
entries: You have a number of sorcery points equal to your sorcerer level, which fuel later abilities and potentially your spells. You regain all spent sorcery points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: At 3rd level, you gain the ability to twist your spells to suit your needs. You gain two of the following Metamagic options of your choice. You gain another one at 10th and 17th level.
You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless otherwise noted.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level sorcerer {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}
Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can do one of the following, representing the magic within you flowing in new ways:

items: Replace one of the options you chose for the Metamagic feature with a different {@filter Metamagic option|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=MM} available to you.
Replace one cantrip you learned from this class's Spellcasting feature with another cantrip from the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|level=0|class=Sorcerer}.

classFeature.name: Magical Guidance
entries: {@i 5th-level sorcerer {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}

You can tap into your inner wellspring of magic to try to conjure success from failure. When you make an ability check that fails, you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll the {@dice d20}, and you must use the new roll, potentially turning the failure into a success.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Recovery
entries: At 7th level, you regain up to your Charisma modifier of expended sorcery points when you finish a short rest. You can recover sorcery points in this way twice, regaining both uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Studies
entries: Starting at 9th level, you can add your Charisma modifier to Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) checks.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: At 10th level, you learn an additional metamagic option.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: At 17th level, you learn an additional metamagic option.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin feature
entries: At 18th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Mystical Awakening
entries: At 20th level, you've become an archon of magic, granting you the following benefits:

items: You can attempt to disrupt foreign magic and absorb it for yourself. When a spell is cast on you, as a reaction you can make an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check against the caster's spell save DC. On a success, you cancel the spell's effects and regain a number of expended sorcery points equal to the spell's level. Once you have successfully absorbed a spell, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

When you cast a spell using a 9th level spell slot, you can attempt to cast it as a higher level spell, going beyond the pre-established mortal limit by expending 2 sorcery points for every level past 9th, up to a maximum of 6 sorcery points. After successfully casting the spell in this way, make a Constitution saving throw equal to 10 + the spell's level. On a failed save, you gain a level of exhaustion for every 2 sorcery points spent in this way.

classFeature.name: Deft Explorer
entries: {@i 1st-level ranger {@variantrule optional class features|TACS|optional feature}, which replaces the Natural Explorer feature}

You are an unsurpassed explorer and survivor, both in the wilderness and in dealing with others on your travels. You gain the Canny benefit below, and you gain an additional benefit below when you reach 6th level and 10th level in this class.

entries.name: Canny
entries: Choose one of your skill proficiencies. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses the chosen skill.
You can also speak, read, and write two additional languages of your choice.

classFeature.name: Favored Enemy
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you have significant experience studying, tracking, hunting, and even talking to a certain type of enemy.

Choose a type of favored enemy: {@filter aberrations|bestiary|type=aberration}, {@filter beasts|bestiary|type=beast}, {@filter celestials|bestiary|type=celestial}, {@filter constructs|bestiary|type=construct}, {@filter dragons|bestiary|type=dragon}, {@filter elementals|bestiary|type=elemental}, {@filter fey|bestiary|type=fey}, {@filter fiends|bestiary|type=fiend}, {@filter giants|bestiary|type=giant}, {@filter monstrosities|bestiary|type=monstrosity}, {@filter oozes|bestiary|type=ooze}, {@filter plants|bestiary|type=plant}, or {@filter undead|bestiary|type=undead}. Alternatively, you can select two races of {@filter humanoid|bestiary|type=humanoid} (such as {@creature gnoll|mm|gnolls} and {@creature orc|mm|orcs}) as favored enemies.
You have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks to track your favored enemies, as well as on Intelligence checks to recall information about them.
When you gain this feature, you also learn one language of your choice that is spoken by your favored enemies, if they speak one at all.

You choose one additional favored enemy, as well as an associated language, at 6th and 14th level. As you gain levels, your choices should reflect the types of monsters you have encountered on your adventures.

classFeature.name: Favored Foe
entries: {@i 1st-level ranger {@variantrule optional class features|TCE|optional feature}, which replaces the Favored Enemy feature and works with the Foe Slayer feature}

When you hit a creature with an attack roll, you can call on your mystical bond with nature to mark the target as your favored enemy for 1 minute or until you lose your concentration (as if you were concentrating on a spell).
The first time on each of your turns that you hit the favored enemy and deal damage to it, including when you mark it, you can increase that damage by {@dice 1d4}.
You can use this feature to mark a favored enemy a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
This feature's extra damage increases when you reach certain levels in this class: to {@dice 1d6} at 6th level and to {@dice 1d8} at 14th level.

classFeature.name: Natural Explorer
entries: You are particularly familiar with one type of natural environment and are adept at traveling and surviving in such regions. Choose one type of favored terrain: arctic, coast, desert, forest, grassland, mountain, swamp, or the Underdark. When you make an Intelligence or Wisdom check related to your favored terrain, your proficiency bonus is doubled if you are using a skill that you're proficient in.
While traveling for an hour or more in your favored terrain, you gain the following benefits:

items: Difficult terrain doesn't slow your group's travel.
Your group can't become lost except by magical means.
Even when you are engaged in another activity while traveling (such as foraging, navigating, or tracking), you remain alert to danger.
If you are traveling alone, you can move stealthily at a normal pace.
When you forage, you find twice as much food as you normally would.
While tracking other creatures, you also learn their exact number, their sizes, and how long ago they passed through the area.

entries: You choose additional favored terrain types at 6th and 10th level.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: At 2nd level, you adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: By the time you reach 2nd level, you have learned to use the magical essence of nature to cast spells, much as a druid does. See {@book chapter 10|TACS|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|phb|11} for the {@filter ranger spell list|spells|class=ranger}.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Ranger table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter ranger spells|spells|class=ranger} of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell animal friendship} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell animal friendship} using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the ranger spell list.

The Spells Known column of the Ranger table shows when you learn more ranger spells of your choice. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 5th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the ranger spells you know and replace it with another spell from the ranger spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your ranger spells, since your magic draws on your attunement to nature. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a ranger spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item druid focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your Ranger spells. You can also use a ranged weapon you are holding as a spellcasting focus, such as a {@item longbow|phb}.

classFeature.name: Primal Awareness
entries: {@i 3rd-level ranger {@variantrule optional class features|TCE|optional feature}, which replaces the Primeval Awareness feature}

You can focus your awareness through the interconnections of nature: you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class if you don't already know them, as shown in the Primal Awareness Spells table. These spells don't count against the number of ranger spells you know.
You can cast each of these spells once without expending a spell slot. Once you cast a spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Primeval Awareness
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, you can use your action and expend one ranger spell slot to focus your awareness on the region around you. For 1 minute per level of the spell slot you expend, you can sense whether the following types of creatures are present within 1 mile of you (or within up to 6 miles if you are in your favored terrain): aberrations, celestials, dragons, elementals, fey, fiends, and undead. This feature doesn't reveal the creatures' location or number.

classFeature.name: Ranger Archetype
entries: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you strive to emulate from the list of available archetypes. Your choice grants features at 3rd level, and again at 7th, 11th, and 15th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Martial Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level ranger {@variantrule optional class features|TCE|optional feature}}

Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace a fighting style you know with another fighting style available to rangers. This replacement represents a shift of focus in your martial practice.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Deft Explorer Improvement
entries: You gain an additional benefit when you reach 6th level in this class.

entries.name: Roving
entries: Your walking speed increases by 5, and you gain a climbing speed and a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

classFeature.name: Favored Enemy and Natural Explorer improvements
entries: At 6th level, you gain an additional favored terrain.
At 6th level, you choose one additional favored enemy, as well as an associated language. Your choice should reflect the types of monsters you have encountered on your adventures.

classFeature.name: Ranger Archetype feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
