The earth beneath your feet erecting from the ground in pillars of stone, the scorching hot flames wreathing off your body burning your foes, coiling water veiling you with a protective barrier, or commanding the wind around you to keep enemies at bay.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Magic
entries: Your knowledge of the elemental planes expands your magical capabilities. You learn spells at certain levels based on an associated element, as detailed on the table below. Once you gain access to one of these spells, it counts as a sorcerer spell for you and does not count towards your number of spells known.
Each of these spells can be swapped for a different elemental spell of the same type and same level by approval of your DM.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Form
entries: Also at 1st level, when you cast a spell from your Primordial Magic feature, you can instantly transform into an embodiment of the element you chose. You appear as an Elemental from that particular plane, for example if you chose Fire then your body would wreathe in flames and your eyes would glow like burning coals.

While in this primordial form, you gain a bonus to damage rolls related to your chosen element equal to your charisma modifier. All the spells listed for your chosen element in your Primordial Magic feature will associate with your chosen element, but the effect is not limited to these spells.
You remain in this primordial form for 1 minute and once you enter this form you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.
Also, you know how to speak, read, and write {@language Primordial}. If you already have {@language Primordial}, you can instead choose a different language.

entries.name: Elemental Spells
entries: Elements such as air, earth, or water are vague about what constitutes associated elements. Best rule of thumb, your DM has the final say, however air could include spells that use thunder or lightning, but not all spells. Whereas earth, water, and air can all be associated with bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing depending on the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Resistance
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage while your Primordial Form is active.
In addition, you always have resistance to a certain damage type based on the element you chose regardless if your primordial form is active or not:

entries.name: Air
entries: You gain resistance to thunder damage.

entries.name: Earth
entries: You gain resistance to acid damage.

entries.name: Fire
entries: You gain resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Water
entries: You gain resistance to cold damage.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Essence
entries: Also at 6th level, when you use a metamagic option on a spell from your Primordial Magic feature, you can regain 1d6 hit points per sorcery point spent on the metamagic option for the spell. You can only gain this magical healing once a round.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Evolution
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can enter your Primordial Form as an action by spending 5 sorcery points. Your Primordial Form now lasts for an hour rather than a minute when you use it in this way. While in your Primordial Form you gain certain benefits depending on the element you chose:

entries.name: Air
entries: You have a magical flying speed of 60 feet and you can hover. In addition, you can pass through spaces as narrow as 1 inch, so long as air can pass through it.

entries.name: Earth
entries: At the start of each of your turns, so long as your feet are touching the ground, you can gain temporary hit points equal to your Charisma modifier. In addition, you have tremorsense out to a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Flames erupt from your body whenever you're in danger, scolding anyone who dares strike you. When a creature within 60 feet of you deals damage to you from an attack, they take 1d10 fire damage.

entries.name: Water
entries: You have a magical swim speed of 60 feet, can breathe underwater as you do air, and while fully submerged in water you can use a bonus action to teleport up to 60 feet to another space that is also underwater.

subclassFeature.name: Elder Elemental
entries: At 18th level, your very being permanently changes as you ascend to the peak of your elemental ancestry. You are always under the effects of your Primordial Form and can shift your appearance to appear as your natural self or your primordial self.
The temporary hit points you'd originally receive when you would enter your primordial form instead are gained after you finish a short or long rest.
In addition, the spell you gained at 1st level from your Primordial Magic feature can be cast at its lowest level without expending a spell slot or requiring material components.

subclassFeature.name: Extraplanar Summoner
entries: {@i 1st-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

Born with a connection to planar magic, sorcerers of this origin are capable of summoning creatures of varying origins. Aberrations, celestials, constructs, fey, fiends, monstrosities, and even undead creatures can be conjured by these odd spellcasters. Your innate magic comes from the other planes, such as the feywild, shadowfell, the outer planes such as the abyss, nine hells, or even mount celestia.

Extraplanar summoners are extremely handy to have due to the powerful allies they can conjure, however they are tied directly to you, so keeping yourself alive is just as important as keeping your ally healthy.

subclassFeature.name: Summoner Magic
entries: Your magic comes from the planes outside the material one, granting you powerful conjuration magic. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Extraplanar Summoner Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be a {@filter conjuration spell from the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;wizard|school=C|level=1;2;3;4;5}.

subclassFeature.name: Extraplanar Ally
entries: {@i 1st-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

As an action, you bind another creature's soul from another plane to your whim and place it within a body you magically conjure. Choose one of the following creature types: aberration, celestial, construct, elemental, fey, fiend, monstrosity, or undead. Depending on the creature type you chose, use the corresponding Extraplanar Ally stat block. The creature obeys your commands and is friendly to you and your allies. It shares your initiative but moves and takes actions either right before or after your turn. If you are reduced to 0 hit points and are knocked unconscious, your connection to the planar ally ends and it returns to the plane from once it came. You can use an action and spend a spell slot of any level to summon it again, but it returns with the hit points and conditions it had prior to returning to its plane.

In addition to summoning the creature, you gain a magical benefit depending on the creature type you chose. You gain one of the following benefits until the Extraplanar Ally is destroyed or returns to its home plane:

entries.name: Aberration
entries: You gain the ability to speak telepathically to creatures you can see within 60 ft of you. In addition, you can reach into the minds of other creatures and cripple them. You can cast the {@spell Vicious Mockery} cantrip as if it were a sorcerer spell for you.

entries.name: Celestial
entries: You gain resistance to radiant damage and can spend your bonus action to heal a creature within 30 ft of you a number of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Construct
entries: You gain resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage and as a bonus action you can change the damage type of your next spell to force damage until the end of your next turn. You concentrate on this effect as if you were concentrating on a spell.

entries.name: Elemental
entries: Choose fire, water, earth, or air. In the Extraplanar Ally (Elemental) statblock you use the features corresponding to the chosen type. You gain resistance to poison damage and have advantage on saving throws against being poisoned.

entries.name: Fey
entries: You gain resistance to psychic damage and you have advantage on saving throws against being charmed.

entries.name: Fiend
entries: You gain resistance to fire damage you can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 60 feet.

entries.name: Monstrosity
entries: You gain a natural weapon in the form of claws or fangs. These natural weapons use your spellcasting ability modifier instead of strength or dexterity for its attack and damage rolls and deal 1d6 slashing or piercing damage (your choice). In addition your armor class increases by half your proficiency bonus (rounded up).

entries.name: Undead
entries: You gain resistance to necrotic damage and whenever you deal damage with a spell you can add an additional amount of necrotic damage to the spell equal to your proficiency bonus.

Your Extraplanar Ally is destroyed when it is reduced to 0 hit points or if it is successfully banished via the Banishment spell, or other similar effect. When it is destroyed, its soul returns to its home plane. It retains no memories from when it was traveling with you while on its home plane and when it is summoned again it regains the lost memories. After your Extraplanar Ally is destroyed, you cannot summon it again until you finish a long rest.

You cannot have more than one Extraplanar Ally at any given time. You can dismiss your Extraplanar Ally as an action, or freely during a short or long rest. Once you dismiss your Extraplanar Ally, you cannot summon a new one until you have finished a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Summoner Savant
entries: {@i 6th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

When you cast a conjuration spell of 1st level or higher, you can choose to ignore the material cost of the spell. When you do so, you must use an arcane focus, but it does not get consumed by the spell.
You use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Synergist
entries: {@i 6th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

Your Extraplanar Ally adds your proficiency bonus to its damage rolls for its weapon attacks. Your Extraplanar's attacks are considered magical for the purposes of overcoming non-magical resistances. In addition, the benefit you gain from your Extraplanar Ally feature gets improved based on the creature type, the following changes (or additions) are made to said benefit:

entries.name: Aberration
entries: You add an additional amount of psychic damage to {@spell Vicious Mockery|PHB} equal to your proficiency bonus and your telepathy's range increases to 120 ft.

entries.name: Celestial
entries: When you heal a creature using the benefit you gain from your Extraplanar Ally feature, you can spend sorcery points up to your proficiency bonus to add 1d4 healing per sorcery point spent.

entries.name: Construct
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being paralyzed.

entries.name: Elemental
entries: You have immunity to poison damage instead of resistance.

entries.name: Fey
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

entries.name: Fiend
entries: You can see normally in darkness, magical or nonmagical, to a range of 120 ft instead of 60ft.

entries.name: Monstrosity
entries: Your speed increases by 15 ft and you gain an amount of temporary hit points equal to twice your proficiency bonus when you gain this feature, finish a long rest, or summon your Extraplanar Ally as a monstrosity.

entries.name: Undead
entries: When you hit a creature with a spell, you can spend 2 sorcery points to make that creature unable to gain the benefits of healing until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Combative Ally
entries: {@i 14th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}
Your Extraplanar Ally gets multiattack, allowing it to make up to two attacks instead of one when it takes the attack action.

In addition, as a bonus action on your turn you can spend a sorcery point to give a number of temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus to your Extraplanar Ally if it is within 60 ft of you.

subclassFeature.name: Extraplanar Master
entries: {@i 18th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

You can summon an Extraplanar Ally two times instead of once before you have to finish a long rest if it is destroyed or dismissed, but you can still only have one summoned Extraplanar Ally at any given time.

In addition when you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, your Extraplanar Ally receives an amount of healing equal to the spell's level plus your proficiency bonus. This healing bypasses its Constructed Body feature.
Your Extraplanar Ally, and creatures you summon using a Conjuration spell of 1st level or higher gain an amount of temporary hit points when they are summoned equal to your sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Sorcery
entries: Blood magic is often used by worshipers of evil gods, demons, or arch devils. Rarely though, some are born to be a blood mage through demonic or devilish origins. Tieflings are strong candidates for becoming blood mages, but anyone of any racial origin has the potential for it. A blood mage is often seen as a sign of some powerful demon or devil seeping into the material plane and killing a blood mage is often associated with keeping said demon or devil in their respective planes. As such, natural born blood mages are hunted and killed.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Magic
entries: {@i 1st-level Sanguine feature}

Your magic comes from the demonic abyss, the infernal nine hells, or even from powerful witches. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Blood Magic Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be an {@filter enchantment or necromancy spell from the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;wizard|school=E,N|level=1;2;3;4;5} or a spell with the hemomancy subschool can be learned regardless of the class or school of magic.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomancy
entries: {@i 1st-level Sanguine feature}

Studying occult-based magic, you've learned the very nature of blood magic and can use it yourself to a limited degree. Your blood magic will be represented by hemomancy dice. These dice are d4s and you have a number of hemomancy dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.

You use these dice to fuel your blood magic abilities, and you regain all of your hemomancy dice after a long rest. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than you can have at your current level in this way. If a hemomancy feature requires a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals your Spell Save DC.

When you use a Hemomancy die, regardless if it is spent or not, you roll the die and take damage equal to what you roll. Your hemomancy dice grows stronger with you as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 5th level, a d8 at 9th level, a d10 at 13th level, and a d12 at 17th level.
You can use your hemomancy dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Blood-Homing Spell
entries: When you make a spell attack you can use a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the attack roll. If it hits, you deal an additional amount of necrotic damage equal to the number rolled. You spend the hemomancy die only if you hit.

entries.name: Blood-Bursting Magic
entries: When you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can spend a hemomancy die to release outward a burst of necromantic energy. Each creature of your choice within 10 feet of you takes necrotic damage equal to the number rolled on the hemomancy die plus your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Bolstering Magic
entries: {@i 6th-level Sanguine feature}

Your innate blood magic allows you to manipulate your spells more efficiently. When you use a metamagic option that would ordinarily spend sorcery points, you can choose to spend hemomancy dice for every sorcery point that would have been used. You still roll the hemomancy dice and take damage equal to what you roll as normal.

Also, you can use a bonus action to spend a sorcery point to regain a spent hemomancy die. You can use this bonus action a number times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Resistance
entries: {@i 6th-level Sanguine feature}
You have resistance to poison and necrotic damage and you have advantage on saving throws made to resist being poisoned or diseased.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Magic
entries: {@i 14th-level Sanguine feature}

During short moments of respite you can regain some of your lost sorcerous power. When you finish a short rest, you can spend a hit die to regain sorcery points equal to the number rolled. You can only spend a hit die in this way once, regaining the ability to do so again when you complete a long rest.
In addition, the following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Sanguine Spell
entries: Your blood magic can be used to empower your magic further. When you make an ability check for a spell you cast, you can roll a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the d20. You spend the hemomancy die only if the check is successful.

entries.name: Blood Concentrate
entries: When your body fails your magic, you can draw on power to endure further. When you would drop concentration on a spell, you can spend a hemomancy die to maintain that concentration. The damage you take from this ability does not break concentration on said spell.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Transformation
entries: {@i 18th-level Sanguine feature}
Your mastery over blood magic has further changed your body permanently, granting you immunity to necrotic damage and immunity to being diseased.

In addition, you can undergo a more powerful transformation which furthers your mastery over said magic. You learn the spell {@spell Guise of the Blood Witch|TACS} and it counts as a sorcerer spell for you but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. You can cast the spell without requiring material components and you can cast it without expending a spell slot by spending 6 hemomancy dice instead. You can cast the spell in this way once, regaining the ability to do so again when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Nature Child
entries: You have a unique bond with nature that allows you to innately call on its magic. Whether you were a magical phenomenon or perhaps you were born into a family of druids, your connection to the weave, the material world, and the primordial elements are all interconnected.

subclassFeature.name: Nature Magic
entries: Your link to nature allows you to learn spells from the druid class. When your Spellcasting feature lets you learn or replace a sorcerer cantrip or a sorcerer spell of 1st level or higher, you can choose the new spell from the druid spell list or the sorcerer spell list. You must otherwise obey all the restrictions for selecting the spell, and it becomes a sorcerer spell for you.

In addition, choose a terrain for the source of your origins: forest, tundra, desert, coast, or mountain. You learn additional spells based on that terrain and your level in this class, as shown below. They are sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of sorcerer spells known. If you later replace any of these  spells, you must replace it with a spell from the druid spell list.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Grace
entries: Starting at 1st level, when you cast one of the spells granted to you by your Nature Magic feature, you gain {@dice 2d4} + your proficiency bonus temporary hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Remedies
entries: At 6th level, you can call on your innate connection to nature to heal your allies. As a bonus action, you can spend any number of sorcery points up to your proficiency bonus and have one creature you can see within 60 feet of you (you can choose yourself) regain {@dice 1d6} hit points per sorcery point spent. You add your Charisma modifier to the total. This healing has no effect on undead or constructs.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Form
entries: At 14th level, you can summon your magic to allow yourself to transform into your true nature. As a bonus action, you gain the following benefits for 1 minute, or until you end the form as a bonus action.

items: Your AC equals 13 + your Dexterity modifier.

You have natural weapons which are unarmed strikes which count as simple weapons. They deal {@dice 2d8} slashing, piercing, or bludgeoning damage on hit (you choose when you attack). You can add your Charisma modifier to the attack and damage rolls instead of Strength.
You gain temporary hit points equal to twice your sorcerer level.

You gain one of the improvements: a flying speed of 30 feet, a climbing speed of 60 feet, a swimming speed of 60 feet and the ability to breathe underwater as you do air, or a burrow speed of 30 feet and tremorsense out to a range of 60 feet.
You ignore difficult terrain.

entries: Once you've transformed, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest or if you have no remaining uses, you can spend 5 sorcery points to transform again.
You choose what your form looks like, but typically it resembles a bestial or plant-like appearance associated with your terrain origin.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Evolution
entries: Starting at 18th level, your body has permanently changed. When you finish a long rest, choose one of the benefits listed in your Natural Form feature, you gain that improvement until you next finish a long rest. After which you can either choose another improvement or the same one to gain again.

subclassFeature.name: Fey Child
entries: You have a unique bond with nature that allows you to innately call on its magic. Whether you were a magical phenomenon or perhaps you were born into a family of druids, your connection to the weave, the material world, and the primordial elements are all interconnected.

subclassFeature.name: Fey Gift
entries: Your link to nature allows you to learn spells from the druid class. When your Spellcasting feature lets you learn or replace a sorcerer cantrip or a sorcerer spell of 1st level or higher, you can choose the new spell from the druid spell list or the sorcerer spell list. You must otherwise obey all the restrictions for selecting the spell, and it becomes a sorcerer spell for you.

In addition, choose a terrain for the source of your origins: forest, tundra, desert, coast, or mountain. You learn additional spells based on that terrain and your level in this class, as shown below. They are sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of sorcerer spells known. If you later replace any of these  spells, you must replace it with a spell from the druid spell list.

rows: Your skin color changes to a bright variant depending on the season. Blue for Winter, pink for Spring, green for Summer, orange for autumn.
Your mood changes your scent, with anger making you smell like a lit flame and happiness making you smell like a blossoming flower, as examples.
You have bark-like antlers sprouting from your head, similarly to horns.
Your voice echoes ever so slightly. Enough to be noticed, but not quite enough to be intolerable.
You have vines for hair, and at the start of every dawn you sprout fresh sweet berries from them.
Your eyes have a swirling magical pattern to them.

subclassFeature.name: Fey Magic
entries: Due to your ancestry, you gain access to various mischievous talents using your magic. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Fey Magic table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be an enchantment or illusion spell from the {@filter bard, sorcerer, or warlock spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;bard|school=E,I|level=1;2;3;4;5}.

subclassFeature.name: Fey Misplacement
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can temporarily step between the feywild and the material plane. When you cast a spell using a spell slot of 1st-level or higher, you can immediately use a bonus action to teleport to an unoccupied space you can see within 30 feet. You can teleport before or after you cast the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Lamenting Spells
entries: At 6th level, you can imbue your magic with the magic of the feywild and sow doubt into a creature. When you damage a creature with a spell, you can spend a sorcery point to deal an additional 2d6 psychic damage. You can spend additional sorcery points to deal an additional {@dice 1d6} psychic damage per sorcery point spent.
The maximum number of sorcery points you can spend on this feature, including the initial one spent, is equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Lost in Dreams
entries: At 14th level, when taking a long rest you can fade into a misty dream-like state where you are visited by friends from the feywild. During this time, to every other creature you are incapacitated. Your body is blinded and deafened in the material plane, but your consciousness drifts to a strange demi-plane where you can move, take actions, speak, see and hear.

You return to your physical body when the long rest is complete, upon returning you have a magical gift from your feywild friends. Choose one of the following benefits, which lasts until your next long rest:

items.name: Fey Immunities
items.entry: You are immune to being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

items.name: Misty Doppelganger
items.entry: When you are targeted for an attack, you can spend your reaction to cause the attacker to roll the attack at disadvantage, as a misty form of yourself redirects their attack, potentially causing them to miss.

items.name: Dream Walker
items.entry: You can cast the {@spell dream} spell without requiring material components and casting the spell requires an action rather than a minute, and you can target creatures that don't normally sleep, causing them to receive a dream-like vision as opposed to an actual dream. They must still be resting in their usual way in order to receive this vision.

subclassFeature.name: Archfey's Blessing
entries: At 18th level, your connection to the feywild has brought you in contact with an Archfey, which now visits you in your dream-like states. When you finish a long rest, you gain the following benefits, which lasts until your next long rest:

items: You can add your Charisma modifier to your Intelligence and Wisdom saving throws. You can do so twice, and you can choose to do so before or after the roll, but before the outcome is decided.
You can use a bonus action to turn {@condition invisible} for 1 minute. You can do so three times.
When you spend hit dice during a short rest to regain hit points, you can add your Charisma modifier to the total amount regained.
You can add your Charisma modifier to the damage rolls of your cantrips.

subclassFeature.name: Drakewarden
entries: Your connection to the natural world takes the form of a draconic spirit, which can manifest in physical form as a drake. As your powers grow, your drake grows as well, blossoming from a small four-legged companion to a majestic winged creature large and strong enough for you to ride. Along the way, you gain an increasing share of the awe-inspiring power of dragons.
Consider the source of the draconic spirit you have bonded with. The Drakewarden Origin table offers examples.

entries.caption: Drakewarden Origin
rows: You studied a dragon's scale or claw, or a trinket from a dragon's hoard, creating your bond through that token's lingering draconic magic.
A secret order of rangers who collect and guard draconic lore taught you their ways.
A dragon gave you a geode or gemstone to care for. To your surprise, the drake hatched from that stone.
You ingested a few drops of dragon blood, forever infusing your nature magic with draconic power.
An ancient Draconic inscription on a standing stone empowered you when you read it aloud.
You had a vivid dream of a mysterious figure accompanied by seven yellow canaries, who warned you of impending doom. When you awoke, your drake was there, watching you.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Gift
entries: {@i 3rd-level Drakewarden feature}
The bond you share with your drake creates a connection to dragonkind, granting you understanding and empowering your presence. You gain the following benefits:

items.name: Thaumaturgy
items.entry: You learn the {@spell thaumaturgy} cantrip, which is a ranger spell for you.

items.name: Tongue of Dragons
items.entry: You learn to speak, read, and write Draconic or one other language of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Drake Companion
entries: {@i 3rd-level Drakewarden feature}
As an action, you can magically summon the drake that is bound to you. It appears in an unoccupied space of your choice within 30 feet of you.

The drake is friendly to you and your companions, and it obeys your commands. See its game statistics in the accompanying {@creature Drake Companion|FTD} stat block, which uses your proficiency bonus (PB) in several places. Whenever you summon the drake, choose a damage type listed in its Draconic Essence trait. You can determine the cosmetic characteristics of the drake, such as its color, its scale texture, or any visible effect of its Draconic Essence; your choice has no effect on its game statistics.

In combat, the drake shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but the only action it takes on its turn is the {@action Dodge} action, unless you take a bonus action on your turn to command it to take another action. That action can be one in its stat block or some other action. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, the drake can take any action of its choice, not just {@action Dodge}.

The drake remains until it is reduced to 0 hit points, until you use this feature to summon the drake again, or until you die. Anything the drake was wearing or carrying is left behind when the drake vanishes.
Once you summon the drake, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend a spell slot of 1st level or higher to summon it.

subclassFeature.name: Bond of Fang and Scale
entries: {@i 7th-level Drakewarden feature}

The bond you share with your drake intensifies, protecting you and stoking the drake's fury. When you summon your drake, it grows wings on its back and gains a flying speed equal to its walking speed.
In addition, while your drake is summoned, you and the drake gain the following benefits:

items.name: Drake Mount
entries: The drake grows to Medium size. Reflecting your special bond, you can use the drake as a mount if your size is Medium or smaller. While you are riding your drake, it can't use the flying speed of this feature.

items.name: Magic Fang
entries: The drake's Bite attack deals an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of the type chosen for the drake's Draconic Essence.

items.name: Resistance
entries: You gain resistance to the damage type chosen for the drake's Draconic Essence.

subclassFeature.name: Drake's Breath
entries: {@i 11th-level Drakewarden feature}

As an action, you can exhale a 30-foot cone of damaging breath or cause your drake to exhale it. Choose acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage (your choice doesn't have to match your drake's Draconic Essence). Each creature in the cone must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 8d6} damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
This damage increases to {@dice 10d6} when you reach 15th level in this class.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend a spell slot of 3rd level or higher to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Perfected Bond
entries: {@i 15th-level Drakewarden feature}
Your bond to your drake reaches the pinnacle of its power. While your drake is summoned, you and the drake gain the following benefits:

items.name: Empowered Bite
entries: The drake's Bite attack deals an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of the type chosen for its Draconic Essence (for a total of {@damage 2d6} extra damage).

items.name: Large Drake
entries: The drake grows to Large size. When you ride your drake, it is no longer prohibited from using the flying speed of Bond of Fang and Scale.

items.name: Reflexive Resistance
entries: When either you or the drake takes damage while you're within 30 feet of each other, you can use your reaction to give yourself or the drake resistance to that instance of damage. You can use this reaction a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Beast Master
entries: The Beast Master archetype embodies a friendship between the civilized races and the beasts of the world. United in focus, beast and ranger work as one to fight the monstrous foes that threaten civilization and the wilderness alike. Emulating the Beast Master archetype means committing yourself to this ideal, working in partnership with an animal as its companion and friend.

subclassFeature.name: Primal Companion
entries: {@i 3rd-level Beast Master variant feature, which replaces the Ranger's Companion feature}

You magically summon a primal beast, which draws strength from your bond with nature. The beast is friendly to you and your companions and obeys your commands. Choose its stat block{@creature Beast of the Land|TCE}, {@creature Beast of the Sea|TCE}, or {@creature Beast of the Sky|TCE}which uses your proficiency bonus (PB) in several places. You also determine the kind of animal the beast is, choosing a kind appropriate for the stat block. Whatever kind you choose, the beast bears primal markings, indicating its mystical origin.

In combat, the beast acts during your turn. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but the only action it takes is the {@action Dodge} action, unless you take a bonus action on your turn to command it to take another action. That action can be one in its stat block or some other action. You can also sacrifice one of your attacks when you take the {@action Attack} action to command the beast to take the {@action Attack} action. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, the beast can take any action of its choice, not just {@action Dodge}.

If the beast has died within the last hour, you can use your action to touch it and expend a spell slot of 1st level or higher. The beast returns to life after 1 minute with all its hit points restored.

When you finish a long rest, you can summon a different primal beast. The new beast appears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you, and you choose its stat block and appearance. If you already have a beast from this feature, it vanishes when the new beast appears. The beast also vanishes if you die.

subclassFeature.name: Ranger's Companion
entries: You gain a beast companion that accompanies you on your adventures and is trained to fight alongside you. Choose a {@filter beast that is no larger than Medium and that has a challenge rating of 1/4 or lower|bestiary|challenge rating=[&0;&1/4]|type=beast|size=f;d;t;s;m|miscellaneous=!swarm}. Add your proficiency bonus to the beast's AC, attack rolls, and damage rolls, as well as to any saving throws and skills it is proficient in. Its hit point maximum equals its normal maximum or four times your ranger level, whichever is higher. Like any creature, the beast can spend Hit Dice during a short rest.

The beast obeys your commands as best as it can. It takes its turn on your initiative. On your turn, you can verbally command the beast where to move (no action required by you). You can use your action to verbally command it to take the {@action Attack}, {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Help} action. If you don't issue a command, the beast takes the {@action Dodge} action. Once you have the Extra Attack feature, you can make one weapon attack yourself when you command the beast to take the {@action Attack} action.

If you are {@condition incapacitated} or absent, your beast companion acts on its own, focusing on protecting you and itself. It never requires your command to use its reaction, such as when making an opportunity attack.
While traveling through your favored terrain with only the beast, you can move stealthily at a normal pace.
If the beast dies, you can obtain another one by spending 8 hours magically bonding with another beast that isn't hostile to you, either the same type of beast as before or a different one.

subclassFeature.name: Exceptional Training
entries: Beginning at 7th level, on any of your turns when your beast companion doesn't attack, you can use a bonus action to command the beast to take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Help} action on its turn. In addition, the beast's attacks now count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

subclassFeature.name: Bestial Fury
entries: Starting at 11th level, when you command your beast companion to take the {@action Attack} action, the beast can make two attacks, or it can take the Multiattack action if it has that action.

subclassFeature.name: Share Spells
entries: Beginning at 15th level, when you cast a spell targeting yourself, you can also affect your beast companion with the spell if the beast is within 30 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter
entries: Emulating the Hunter archetype means accepting your place as a bulwark between civilization and the terrors of the wilderness. As you walk the Hunter's path, you learn specialized techniques for fighting the threats you face, from rampaging ogres and hordes of orcs to towering giants and terrifying dragons.

subclassFeature.name: Horde Breaker
entries: Once on each of your turns when you make a weapon attack, you can make another attack with the same weapon against a different creature that is within 5 feet of the original target and within range of your weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter's Prey
entries: At 3rd level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Colossus Slayer
entries: Your tenacity can wear down the most potent foes. When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, the creature takes an extra {@damage 1d8} damage if it's below its hit point maximum. You can deal this extra damage only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Giant Killer
entries: When a Large or larger creature within 5 feet of you hits or misses you with an attack, you can use your reaction to attack that creature immediately after its attack, provided that you can see the creature.

subclassFeature.name: Defensive Tactics
entries: At 7th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Escape the Horde
entries: Opportunity attacks against you are made with disadvantage.

subclassFeature.name: Multiattack Defense
entries: When a creature hits you with an attack, you gain a +4 bonus to AC against all subsequent attacks made by that creature for the rest of the turn.

subclassFeature.name: Steel Will
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

subclassFeature.name: Multiattack
entries: At 11th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Volley
entries: You can use your action to make a ranged attack against any number of creatures within 10 feet of a point you can see within your weapon's range. You must have ammunition for each target, as normal, and you make a separate attack roll for each target.

subclassFeature.name: Whirlwind Attack
entries: You can use your action to make a melee attack against any number of creatures within 5 feet of you, with a separate attack roll for each target.

subclassFeature.name: Evasion
entries: You can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as a red dragon's fiery breath or a {@spell lightning bolt} spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

subclassFeature.name: Stand Against the Tide
entries: When a hostile creature misses you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to force that creature to repeat the same attack against another creature (other than itself) of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Superior Hunter's Defense
entries: At 15th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack's damage against you.

subclassFeature.name: Fey Wanderer
entries: A fey mystique surrounds you, thanks to the boon of an archfey, the shining fruit you ate from a talking tree, the magic spring you swam in, or some other auspicious event. However you acquired your fey magic, you are now a Fey Wanderer, a ranger who represents both the mortal and the fey realms. As you wander the multiverse, your joyful laughter brightens the hearts of the downtrodden, and your martial prowess strikes terror in your foes, for great is the mirth of the fey and dreadful is their fury.

subclassFeature.name: Dreadful Strikes
entries: {@i 3rd-level Fey Wanderer feature}

You can augment your weapon strikes with mind-scarring magic, drawn from the gloomy hollows of the Feywild. When you hit a creature with a weapon, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d4} psychic damage to the target, which can take this extra damage only once per turn.
The extra damage increases to {@dice 1d6} when you reach 11th level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Fey Wanderer Magic
entries: {@i 3rd-level Fey Wanderer feature}

You learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Fey Wanderer Spells table. Each spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.
You also possess a preternatural blessing from a fey ally or a place of fey power. Choose your blessing from the Feywild Gifts table or determine it randomly.

entries.caption: Feywild Gifts
rows: Illusory butterflies flutter around you while you take a short or long rest.
Fresh, seasonal flowers sprout from your hair each dawn.
You faintly smell of cinnamon, lavender, nutmeg, or another comforting herb or spice.
Your shadow dances while no one is looking directly at it.
Horns or antlers sprout from your head.
Your skin and hair change color to match the season at each dawn.

subclassFeature.name: Otherworldly Glamour
entries: {@i 3rd-level Fey Wanderer feature}
Your fey qualities give you a supernatural charm. As a result, whenever you make a Charisma check, you gain a bonus to the check equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of +1).
In addition, you gain proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: {@skill Deception}, {@skill Performance}, or {@skill Persuasion}.

subclassFeature.name: Beguiling Twist
entries: {@i 7th-level Fey Wanderer feature}
The magic of the Feywild guards your mind. You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

In addition, whenever you or a creature you can see within 120 feet of you succeeds on a saving throw against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}, you can use your reaction to force a different creature you can see within 120 feet of you to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. If the save fails, the target is {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} by you (your choice) for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a successful save.

subclassFeature.name: Fey Reinforcements
entries: {@i 11th-level Fey Wanderer feature}

The royal courts of the Feywild have blessed you with the assistance of fey beings: you know {@spell summon fey|tce}. It doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know, and you can cast it without a material component. You can also cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest.
Whenever you start casting the spell, you can modify it so that it doesn't require concentration. If you do so, the spell's duration becomes 1 minute for that casting.

subclassFeature.name: Misty Wanderer
entries: {@i 15th-level Fey Wanderer feature}

You can slip in and out of the Feywild to move in a blink of an eye: you can cast {@spell misty step} without expending a spell slot. You can do so a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

In addition, whenever you cast {@i misty step}, you can bring along one willing creature you can see within 5 feet of you. That creature teleports to an unoccupied space of your choice within 5 feet of your destination space.

subclassFeature.name: Swarmkeeper
entries: Feeling a deep connection to the environment around them, some rangers reach out through their magical connection to the world and bond with a swarm of nature spirits. The swarm becomes a potent force in battle, as well as helpful company for the ranger. Some Swarmkeepers are outcasts or hermits, keeping to themselves and their attendant swarms rather than dealing with the discomfort of others. Other Swarmkeepers enjoy building vibrant communities that work for the mutual benefit of all those they consider part of their swarm.

subclassFeature.name: Gathered Swarm
entries: {@i 3rd-level Swarmkeeper feature}

A swarm of intangible nature spirits has bonded itself to you and can assist you in battle. While you're alive, the swarm remains in your space, crawling on you or flying and skittering around you within your space. You determine its appearance, or you generate its appearance by rolling on the Swarm Appearance table.
Once on each of your turns, you can cause the swarm to assist you in one of the following ways, immediately after you hit a creature with an attack:

items: The attack's target takes {@damage 1d6} piercing damage from the swarm.
The attack's target must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC or be moved by the swarm up to 15 feet horizontally in a direction of your choice.
You are moved by the swarm 5 feet horizontally in a direction of your choice.

entries.name: It's Your Swarm
entries: A Swarmkeeper's swarm and spells are reflections of the character's bond with nature spirits. Take the opportunity to describe the swarm and the ranger's magic in play. For example, when your ranger casts gaseous form, they might appear to melt into the swarm, instead of a cloud of mist, or the {@spell arcane eye} spell could create an extension of your swarm that spies for you. Such descriptions don't change the effects of spells, but they are an exciting opportunity to explore your character's narrative through their class abilities. For more guidance on customizing spells, see the "Personalizing Spells" section in chapter 3.

Also, remember that the swarm's appearance is yours to customize, and don't feel confined to a single appearance. Perhaps the spirits' look changes with the ranger's mood or with the seasons. You decide!

subclassFeature.name: Swarmkeeper Magic
entries: {@i 3rd-level Swarmkeeper feature}
You learn the {@spell mage hand} cantrip if you don't already know it. When you cast it, the hand takes the form of your swarming nature spirits.

You also learn an additional spell of 1st level or higher when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Swarmkeeper Spells table. Each spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Writhing Tide
entries: {@i 7th-level Swarmkeeper feature}

You can condense part of your swarm into a focused mass that lifts you up. As a bonus action, you gain a flying speed of 10 feet and can hover. This effect lasts for 1 minute or until you are {@condition incapacitated}.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Mighty Swarm
entries: {@i 11th-level Swarmkeeper feature}
Your Gathered Swarm grows mightier in the following ways:

items: The damage of Gathered Swarm increases to {@dice 1d8}.
If a creature fails its saving throw against being moved by Gathered Swarm, you can also cause the swarm to knock the creature {@condition prone}.
When you are moved by Gathered Swarm, it gives you half cover until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Swarming Dispersal
entries: {@i 15th-level Swarmkeeper feature}

You can discorporate into your swarm, avoiding danger. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to give yourself resistance to that damage. You vanish into your swarm and then teleport to an unoccupied space that you can see within 30 feet of you, where you reappear with the swarm.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Gloom Stalker
entries: Gloom Stalkers are at home in the darkest places: deep under the earth, in gloomy alleyways, in primeval forests, and wherever else the light dims. Most folk enter such places with trepidation, but a Gloom Stalker ventures boldly into the darkness, seeking to ambush threats before they can reach the broader world. Such rangers are often found in the Underdark, but they will go any place where evil lurks in the shadows.

subclassFeature.name: Gloom Stalker Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Gloom Stalker Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Umbral Sight
entries: At 3rd level, you gain {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have {@sense darkvision} from your race, its range increases by 30 feet.

You are also adept at evading creatures that rely on {@sense darkvision}. While in darkness, you are {@condition invisible} to any creature that relies on {@sense darkvision} to see you in that darkness.

subclassFeature.name: Dread Ambusher
entries: At 3rd level, you master the art of the ambush. You can give yourself a bonus to your initiative rolls equal to your Wisdom modifier.

At the start of your first turn of each combat, your walking speed increases by 10 feet, which lasts until the end of that turn. If you take the {@action Attack} action on that turn, you can make one additional weapon attack as part of that action. If that attack hits, the target takes an extra 1d8 damage of the weapon's damage type.

subclassFeature.name: Iron Mind
entries: By 7th level, you have honed your ability to resist the mind-altering powers of your prey. You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws. If you already have this proficiency, you instead gain proficiency in Intelligence or Charisma saving throws (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Stalker's Flurry
entries: At 11th level, you learn to attack with such unexpected speed that you can turn a miss into another strike. Once on each of your turns when you miss with a weapon attack, you can make another weapon attack as part of the same action.

subclassFeature.name: Shadowy Dodge
entries: Starting at 15th level, you can dodge in unforeseen ways, with wisps of supernatural shadow around you. Whenever a creature makes an attack roll against you and doesn't have advantage on the roll, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on it. You must use this feature before you know the outcome of the attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: Horizon Walker
entries: Horizon Walkers guard the world against threats that originate from other planes or that seek to ravage the mortal realm with otherworldly magic. They seek out planar portals and keep watch over them, venturing to the Inner Planes and the Outer Planes as needed to pursue their foes. These rangers are also friends to any forces in the multiverseespecially benevolent dragons, fey, and elementalsthat work to preserve life and the order of the planes.

subclassFeature.name: Detect Portal
entries: At 3rd level, you gain the ability to magically sense the presence of a planar portal. As an action, you detect the distance and direction to the closest planar portal within 1 mile of you.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.
See the "Planar Travel" section in chapter 2 of the Dungeon Master's Guide for examples of planar portals.

subclassFeature.name: Horizon Walker Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Horizon Walker Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Planar Warrior
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to draw on the energy of the multiverse to augment your attacks.

As a bonus action, choose one creature you can see within 30 feet of you. The next time you hit that creature on this turn with a weapon attack, all damage dealt by the attack becomes force damage, and the creature takes an extra {@damage 1d8} force damage from the attack. When you reach 11th level in this class, the extra damage increases to {@dice 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Ethereal Step
entries: At 7th level, you learn to step through the Ethereal Plane. As a bonus action, you can cast the {@spell etherealness} spell with this feature, without expending a spell slot, but the spell ends at the end of the current turn.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Distant Strike
entries: At 11th level, you gain the ability to pass between the planes in the blink of an eye. When you take the {@action Attack} action, you can teleport up to 10 feet before each attack to an unoccupied space you can see.
If you attack at least two different creatures with the action, you can make one additional attack with it against a third creature.

subclassFeature.name: Spectral Defense
entries: At 15th level, your ability to move between planes enables you to slip through the planar boundaries to lessen the harm done to you during battle. When you take damage from an attack, you can use your reaction to give yourself resistance to all of that attack's damage on this turn.

subclassFeature.name: Monster Slayer
entries: You have dedicated yourself to hunting down creatures of the night and wielders of grim magic. A Monster Slayer seeks out vampires, dragons, evil fey, fiends, and other magical threats. Trained in supernatural techniques to overcome such monsters, slayers are experts at unearthing and defeating mighty, mystical foes.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter's Sense
entries: At 3rd level, you gain the ability to peer at a creature and magically discern how best to hurt it. As an action, choose one creature you can see within 60 feet of you. You immediately learn whether the creature has any damage immunities, resistances, or vulnerabilities and what they are. If the creature is hidden from divination magic, you sense that it has no damage immunities, resistances, or vulnerabilities.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Monster Slayer Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Monster Slayer Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Slayer's Prey
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can focus your ire on one foe, increasing the harm you inflict on it. As a bonus action, you designate one creature you can see within 60 feet of you as the target of this feature. The first time each turn that you hit that target with a weapon attack, it takes an extra {@damage 1d6} damage from the weapon.
This benefit lasts until you finish a short or long rest. It ends early if you designate a different creature.

subclassFeature.name: Supernatural Defense
entries: At 7th level, you gain extra resilience against your prey's assaults on your mind and body. Whenever the target of your Slayer's Prey forces you to make a saving throw and whenever you make an ability check to escape that target's grapple, add {@dice 1d6} to your roll.

subclassFeature.name: Magic-User's Nemesis
entries: At 11th level, you gain the ability to thwart someone else's magic. When you see a creature casting a spell or teleporting within 60 feet of you, you can use your reaction to try to magically foil it. The creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC, or its spell or teleport fails and is wasted.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Slayer's Counter
entries: At 15th level, you gain the ability to counterattack when your prey tries to sabotage you. If the target of your Slayer's Prey forces you to make a saving throw, you can use your reaction to make one weapon attack against the quarry. You make this attack immediately before making the saving throw. If your attack hits, your save automatically succeeds, in addition to the attack's normal effects.

subclassFeature.name: Winter Walker
entries: You traverse primarily through colder environments. Tundras, certain layers of hell, perhaps even throughout the coldest parts of the feywild. Adapting to this specific environment, your magic also adapts to it, granting you certain cryomantic abilities.

subclassFeature.name: Freezing Strikes
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can augment your weapon strikes with body numbing magic, drawn from the frozen wastes of the tundras you traverse. When you hit a creature with a weapon, you can deal an extra 1d6 cold damage and their speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of your next turn, you can only apply this extra damage and speed reduction once per turn.
The extra damage increases to 1d8 when you reach 11th level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Winter Walker Magic
entries: You learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Winter Walker Spells table. Each spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Frost Walker
entries: Also at 3rd level, you are adept at traversing through snowy environments and are an expert at guiding your allies through said environments. You have advantage on saving throws made to resist the effects of extreme cold and you do not suffer the effects of difficult terrain from ice and snow. By spending 10 minutes, you can magically bestow this benefit to any number of creatures within 30 feet of you up to your proficiency bonus plus your Wisdom modifier. This benefit lasts for 8 hours and once you grant it, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

If you chose the arctic terrain as your favored terrain from the Natural Explorer feature, you can grant this magical benefit as an action rather than spending 10 minutes and you can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest. When you use an action to grant these benefits, it instead only lasts for a minute.

subclassFeature.name: Warden of Winter
entries: At 7th level, you are aware of the dangers that lurk in the coldest of environments and your study over these creatures allows you to better prepare for them. You have resistance to cold damage and you have advantage on ability checks and saving throws made against effects that would reduce your movement in any way, including ways that would indirectly affect your speed such as being {@condition stunned} or {@condition paralyzed} which would take away your ability to move, even though it does not directly reduce your speed.
When you use your Frost Walker feature to grant other creatures the benefits of it, one of those creatures may also magically gain the benefits of this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Sentinel
entries: At 11th level, you can use your magic to ward yourself and your allies with a protective ice barrier. As a bonus action you can grant yourself and a number of allies within 30 feet of you up to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1) temporary hit points equal to your ranger level. While they have these temporary hit points, whenever a creature hits them with a melee attack from within 5 feet of them the attacker takes an amount of cold damage equal to your ranger level.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Preserving Ward
entries: At 15th level, you can use your magic to freeze over a dead creature, extending the duration needed to revive them with spells. You can cast gentle repose without expending a spell slot. You can do so a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

In addition, if you cast gentle repose on a creature whose been dead for no longer than a minute, some of your magic lingers within the corpse and tethers the soul to the creature before it can pass on into the afterlife. The cost for any material needed for a spell to bring the creature back to life, such as revivify, is halved until the spell ends.

subclassFeature.name: The Lore Hunter
entries: Some rangers specialize in the pursuit of knowledge, an archeologist traversing his way through an ancient tomb, hunting for strange and rare artifacts. Rangers of this conclave often dig up old relics of the past and try to decipher them to learn the secrets they hold.

subclassFeature.name: Lore Hunter Magic
entries: You learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Lore Hunter Spells table. Each spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Relic Knowledge
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you've been researching old, forgotten magic for years and have learned how to manifest it by tattooing runes onto your body. You gain proficiency in the History and Arcana skills. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of those proficiencies.
In addition, you have advantage on Intelligence (Investigation) and Wisdom (Perception) checks made to find or detect traps, or to see through illusions.

subclassFeature.name: Blast From the Past
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can empower your attacks with magic from the runes on your body. When you hit a creature with a weapon, you can deal an extra {@dice 1d6} force damage to the target, which can take this extra damage only once per turn.
The extra damage increases to 1d8 when you reach 11th level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Ritual Master
entries: Starting at 7th level, you can cast a ranger spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared. In addition, when you ritual cast a spell, it takes you an extra 5 minutes instead of 10 to cast.

In addition, after you finish a long rest you can choose one of your prepared ranger spells, the chosen spell can be of a level no higher than half of your proficiency bonus (rounded down). The chosen spell is given the ritual tag until you next finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Detect Dungeon
entries: Also at 7th level, you can focus your mind to magically sense dungeons or ruins that contain valuable treasures, such as a dragon's hoard or the temple of an ancient ruler. As an action, you detect the distance and direction to the closest dungeon or ruin within 10 miles of you. In order for a location to qualify for this feature, there must be enough treasure worth at least 1,000 gp or more.

Alternatively, you can name a creature or object associated and/or familiar with the dungeon or ruin and roll an Intelligence (Arcana) ability check. The DC equals the CR of the creature or 15 if it is an object. If the object is a magic item, the DC increases by 5 if it is a Rare or Very Rare item and by 10 if it is a Legendary item or an Artifact. If the target is protected by divination magic, you gain no information about it.
On a successful check, you learn the location of the target, as well as the distance and direction of it. You retain this knowledge for the next 24 hours, after which it is magically lost.
Once you've used this feature using either of the methods above, you cannot use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ancient Wisdom
entries: Starting at 11th level, when you make an Intelligence ability check using a skill or tool, you can add your Wisdom modifier to the roll.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest. While you have no uses available, you can spend a spell slot of any level to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Relics of The Past
entries: Starting at 15th level, you're able to manifest a powerful item using old and forgotten magic. By performing a 1-hour ritual and expending a 3rd level or higher spell slot, you can manifest one of the following items, which lasts until you use this feature again or until you die:

items.name: Relic Talisman
entries: You create a magical talisman which wards the wearer with a protective aura. A creature wearing this talisman gains a +2 bonus to AC and saving throws.

items.name: Relic Armament
entries: You can create a non-magical martial or simple weapon, which becomes magical after it is created. The wielder has a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon and once per turn when they hit with it, it deals an additional {@dice 1d6} force damage.

items.name: Relic Ring
entries: You create a ring capable of storing magic within it. As an action, you can choose one of your prepared ranger spells and store it within the ring. The spell must be no higher than 3rd level. A creature can cast the spell from the ring once, without expending a spell slot or requiring material components. The spell uses your spell save DC and spell attack modifier. You can use an action to choose a different spell to store into the ring, taking out the previous one. Once a creature casts a spell from this ring, a creature cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

items.name: Relic Aegis
entries: You create a set of light or medium non-magical armor, which becomes magical after it is created. The armor gives the wearer a +1 bonus to their AC and the wearer's movement speed is increased by 10 feet.
Once you've manifested an item with this feature, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of the Ancients
entries: The Oath of the Ancients is as old as the race of elves and the rituals of the druids. Sometimes called fey knights, green knights, or horned knights, paladins who swear this oath cast their lot with the side of the light in the cosmic struggle against darkness because they love the beautiful and life-giving things of the world, not necessarily because they believe in principles of honor, courage, and justice. They adorn their armor and clothing with images of growing thingsleaves, antlers, or flowersto reflect their commitment to preserving life and light in the world.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Nature's Wrath
entries: You can use your Channel Divinity to invoke primeval forces to ensnare a foe. As an action, you can cause spectral vines to spring up and reach for a creature within 10 feet of you that you can see. The creature must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (its choice) or be {@condition restrained}. While {@condition restrained} by the vines, the creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. On a success, it frees itself and the vines vanish.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Turn the Faithless
entries: You can use your Channel Divinity to utter ancient words that are painful for fey and fiends to hear. As an action, you present your holy symbol, and each fey or fiend within 30 feet of you that can hear you must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is turned for 1 minute or until it takes damage.

A turned creature must spend its turns trying to move as far away from you as it can, and it can't willingly move to a space within 30 feet of you. It also can't take reactions. For its action, it can use only the {@action Dash} action or try to escape from an effect that prevents it from moving. If there's nowhere to move, the creature can use the {@action Dodge} action.
If the creature's true form is concealed by an illusion, shapeshifting, or other effect, that form is revealed while it is turned.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of the Ancients
entries: The tenets of the Oath of the Ancients have been preserved for uncounted centuries. This oath emphasizes the principles of good above any concerns of law or chaos. Its four central principles are simple.

entries.name: Kindle the Light
entries: Through your acts of mercy, kindness, and forgiveness, kindle the light of hope in the world, beating back despair.

entries.name: Shelter the Light
entries: Where there is good, beauty, love, and laughter in the world, stand against the wickedness that would swallow it. Where life flourishes, stand against the forces that would render it barren.

entries.name: Preserve Your Own Light
entries: Delight in song and laughter, in beauty and art. If you allow the light to die in your own heart, you can't preserve it in the world.

entries.name: Be the Light
entries: Be a glorious beacon for all who live in despair. Let the light of your joy and courage shine forth in all your deeds.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Warding
entries: Beginning at 7th level, ancient magic lies so heavily upon you that it forms an eldritch ward. You and friendly creatures within 10 feet of you have resistance to damage from spells.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Undying Sentinel
entries: Starting at 15th level, when you are reduced to 0 hit points and are not killed outright, you can choose to drop to 1 hit point instead. Once you use this ability, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.
Additionally, you suffer none of the drawbacks of old age, and you can't be aged magically.

subclassFeature.name: Elder Champion
entries: At 20th level, you can assume the form of an ancient force of nature, taking on an appearance you choose. For example, your skin might turn green or take on a bark-like texture, your hair might become leafy or mosslike, or you might sprout antlers or a lion-like mane.
Using your action, you undergo a transformation. For 1 minute, you gain the following benefits:

items: At the start of each of your turns, you regain 10 hit points.
Whenever you cast a paladin spell that has a casting time of 1 action, you can cast it using your bonus action instead.
Enemy creatures within 10 feet of you have disadvantage on saving throws against your paladin spells and Channel Divinity options.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Devotion
entries: The Oath of Devotion binds a paladin to the loftiest ideals of justice, virtue, and order. Sometimes called cavaliers, white knights, or holy warriors, these paladins meet the ideal of the knight in shining armor, acting with honor in pursuit of justice and the greater good. They hold themselves to the highest standards of conduct, and some, for better or worse, hold the rest of the world to the same standards. Many who swear this oath are devoted to gods of law and good and use their gods' tenets as the measure of their devotion. They hold angelsthe perfect servants of goodas their ideals, and incorporate images of angelic wings into their helmets or coats of arms.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Sacred Weapon
entries: As an action, you can imbue one weapon that you are holding with positive energy, using your Channel Divinity. For 1 minute, you add your Charisma modifier to attack rolls made with that weapon (with a minimum bonus of +1). The weapon also emits bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light 20 feet beyond that. If the weapon is not already magical, it becomes magical for the duration.
You can end this effect on your turn as part of any other action. If you are no longer holding or carrying this weapon, or if you fall {@condition unconscious}, this effect ends.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Turn the Unholy
entries: As an action, you present your holy symbol and speak a prayer censuring fiends and undead, using your Channel Divinity. Each fiend or undead that can see or hear you within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw. If the creature fails its saving throw, it is turned for 1 minute or until it takes damage.

A turned creature must spend its turns trying to move as far away from you as it can, and it can't willingly move to a space within 30 feet of you. It also can't take reactions. For its action, it can use only the {@action Dash} action or try to escape from an effect that prevents it from moving. If there's nowhere to move, the creature can use the {@action Dodge} action.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

entries.caption: Oath of Devotion Spells
rows: {@spell protection from evil and good}, {@spell sanctuary}
{@spell freedom of movement}, {@spell guardian of faith}

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Devotion
entries: Though the exact words and strictures of the Oath of Devotion vary, paladins of this oath share these tenets.

entries.name: Honesty
entries: Don't lie or cheat. Let your word be your promise.

entries.name: Courage
entries: Never fear to act, though caution is wise.

entries.name: Compassion
entries: Aid others, protect the weak, and punish those who threaten them. Show mercy to your foes, but temper it with wisdom.

entries.name: Honor
entries: Treat others with fairness, and let your honorable deeds be an example to them. Do as much good as possible while causing the least amount of harm.

entries.name: Duty
entries: Be responsible for your actions and their consequences, protect those entrusted to your care, and obey those who have just authority over you.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Devotion
entries: Starting at 7th level, you and friendly creatures within 10 feet of you can't be {@condition charmed} while you are conscious.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Purity of Spirit
entries: Beginning at 15th level, you are always under the effects of a {@spell protection from evil and good} spell.

subclassFeature.name: Holy Nimbus
entries: At 20th level, as an action, you can emanate an aura of sunlight. For 1 minute, bright light shines from you in a 30-foot radius, and dim light shines 30 feet beyond that.
Whenever an enemy creature starts its turn in the bright light, the creature takes 10 radiant damage.
In addition, for the duration, you have advantage on saving throws against spells cast by fiends or undead.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Vengeance
entries: The Oath of Vengeance is a solemn commitment to punish those who have committed a grievous sin. When evil forces slaughter helpless villagers, when an entire people turns against the will of the gods, when a thieves' guild grows too violent and powerful, when a dragon rampages through the countrysideat times like these, paladins arise and swear an Oath of Vengeance to set right that which has gone wrong. To these paladinssometimes called avengers or dark knightstheir own purity is not as important as delivering justice.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Abjure Enemy
entries: As an action, you present your holy symbol and speak a prayer of denunciation, using your Channel Divinity. Choose one creature within 60 feet of you that you can see. That creature must make a Wisdom saving throw, unless it is immune to being {@condition frightened}. Fiends and undead have disadvantage on this saving throw.

On a failed save, the creature is {@condition frightened} for 1 minute or until it takes any damage. While {@condition frightened}, the creature's speed is 0, and it can't benefit from any bonus to its speed.
On a successful save, the creature's speed is halved for 1 minute or until the creature takes any damage.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Vow of Enmity
entries: As a bonus action, you can utter a vow of enmity against a creature you can see within 10 feet of you, using your Channel Divinity. You gain advantage on attack rolls against the creature for 1 minute or until it drops to 0 hit points or falls {@condition unconscious}.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Vengeance
entries: The tenets of the Oath of Vengeance vary by paladin, but all the tenets revolve around punishing wrongdoers by any means necessary. Paladins who uphold these tenets are willing to sacrifice even their own righteousness to mete out justice upon those who do evil, so the paladins are often neutral or lawful neutral in alignment. The core principles of the tenets are brutally simple.

entries.name: Fight the Greater Evil
entries: Faced with a choice of fighting my sworn foes or combating a lesser evil, I choose the greater evil.

entries.name: No Mercy for the Wicked
entries: Ordinary foes might win my mercy, but my sworn enemies do not.

entries.name: By Any Means Necessary
entries: My qualms can't get in the way of exterminating my foes.

entries.name: Restitution
entries: If my foes wreak ruin on the world, it is because I failed to stop them. I must help those harmed by their misdeeds.

subclassFeature.name: Relentless Avenger
