Tale of the Dragon. The target spews fire from the mouth in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking fire damage equal to four rolls of your Performance die on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Tale of the Angel. The target regains hit points equal to two rolls of your Performance die + your Charisma modifier, and you end one condition from the following list affecting the target: {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition petrified}, or {@condition poisoned}.

Tale of the Mind-Bender. You evoke an incomprehensible fable from an otherworldly being. The target must succeed on an Intelligence saving throw or take psychic damage equal to three rolls of your Performance die and be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Session
entries: {@i 6th-level College of Spirits feature}

Spirits provide you with supernatural insights. You can conduct an hour-long ritual channeling spirits (which can be done during a short or long rest) using your Spiritual Focus. You can conduct the ritual with a number of willing creatures equal to your proficiency bonus (including yourself). At the end of the ritual, you temporarily learn {@filter one spell of your choice from any class|spells|school=d;n|level=0;1;2;3;4;5;6}.

The spell you choose must be of a level equal to the number of creatures that conducted the ritual or less, the spell must be of a level you can cast, and it must be in the school of divination or necromancy. The chosen spell counts as a bard spell for you but doesn't count against the number of bard spells you know.
Once you perform the ritual, you can't do so again until you start a long rest, and you know the chosen spell until you start a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Mystical Connection
entries: {@i 14th-level College of Spirits feature}

You now have the ability to nudge the spirits of Tales from Beyond toward certain tales. Whenever you roll on the Spirit Tales table, you can roll the die twice and choose which of the two effects to bestow. If you roll the same number on both dice, you can ignore the number and choose any effect on the table.

entries.name: Spirit Tales
entries: Storytellers, like bards of the College of Spirits, often give voice to tales inspired by some greater theme or body of work. When determining what stories you tell, consider what unites them. Do they all feature characters from a specific group, like archetypes from the tarokka deck, figures from constellations, childhood imaginary friends, or characters in a particular storybook? Or are your inspirations more general, incorporating historic champions, mythological heroes, or urban legends? Use the tales you tell to define your niche as a storytelling adventurer.

subclassFeature.name: College of Glamour
entries: The College of Glamour is the home of bards who mastered their craft in the vibrant realm of the Feywild or under the tutelage of someone who dwelled there. Tutored by satyrs, eladrin, and other fey, these bards learn to use their magic to delight and captivate others.

The bards of this college are regarded with a mixture of awe and fear. Their performances are the stuff of legend. These bards are so eloquent that a speech or song that one of them performs can cause captors to release the bard unharmed and can lull a furious dragon into complacency. The same magic that allows them to quell beasts can also bend minds. Villainous bards of this college can leech off a community for weeks, misusing their magic to turn their hosts into thralls. Heroic bards of this college instead use this power to gladden the downtrodden and undermine oppressors.

subclassFeature.name: Enthralling Performance
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can charge your performance with seductive, fey magic.

If you perform for at least 1 minute, you can attempt to inspire wonder in your audience by singing, reciting a poem, or dancing. At the end of the performance, choose a number of humanoids within 60 feet of you who watched and listened to all of it, up to a number equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one). Each target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or be {@condition charmed} by you. While {@condition charmed} in this way, the target idolizes you, it speaks glowingly of you to anyone who talks to it, and it hinders anyone who opposes you, although it avoids violence unless it was already inclined to fight on your behalf. This effect ends on a target after 1 hour, if it takes any damage, if you attack it, or if it witnesses you attacking or damaging any of its allies.
If a target succeeds on its saving throw, the target has no hint that you tried to charm it.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Performance
entries: When you join the College of Glamour at 3rd level, you gain the ability to weave a song of fey magic that imbues your allies with vigor and speed.

When you begin a bardic performance, you grant yourself a wondrous appearance. When you do so, choose any number of creatures affected by your bardic performance you can see and that can see you within range. Each of them gains 5 temporary hit points. When a creature gains these temporary hit points, it can immediately use its reaction to move up to its speed, without provoking opportunity attacks.
The number of temporary hit points increases when you reach certain levels in this class, increasing to 8 at 5th level, 11 at 10th level, and 14 at 15th level.

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Majesty
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to cloak yourself in a fey magic that makes others want to serve you. As a bonus action, you cast {@spell command}, without expending a spell slot, and you take on an appearance of unearthly beauty for 1 minute or until your concentration ends (as if you were concentrating on a spell). During this time, you can cast {@spell command} as a bonus action on each of your turns, without expending a spell slot.
Any creature {@condition charmed} by you automatically fails its saving throw against the {@spell command} you cast with this feature.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Unbreakable Majesty
entries: At 14th level, your appearance permanently gains an otherworldly aspect that makes you look more lovely and fierce.

In addition, as a bonus action, you can assume a magically majestic presence for 1 minute or until you are {@condition incapacitated}. For the duration, whenever any creature tries to attack you for the first time on a turn, the attacker must make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, it can't attack you on this turn, and it must choose a new target for its attack or the attack is wasted. On a successful save, it can attack you on this turn, but it has disadvantage on any saving throw it makes against your spells on your next turn.
Once you assume this majestic presence, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: College of Swords
entries: Bards of the College of Swords are called blades, and they entertain through daring feats of weapon prowess. Blades perform stunts such as sword swallowing, knife throwing and juggling, and mock combats. Though they use their weapons to entertain, they are also highly trained and skilled warriors in their own right.

Their talent with weapons inspires many blades to lead double lives. One blade might use a circus troupe as cover for nefarious deeds such as assassination, robbery, and blackmail. Other blades strike at the wicked, bringing justice to bear against the cruel and powerful. Most troupes are happy to accept a blade's talent for the excitement it adds to a performance, but few entertainers fully trust a blade in their ranks.

Blades who abandon their lives as entertainers have often run into trouble that makes maintaining their secret activities impossible. A blade caught stealing or engaging in vigilante justice is too great a liability for most troupes. With their weapon skills and magic, these blades either take up work as enforcers for thieves' guilds or strike out on their own as adventurers.

subclassFeature.name: Blade Flourish
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to perform impressive displays of martial prowess and speed.

While your bardic performance is active, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn, your walking speed increases by 10 feet until the end of the turn, and if a weapon attack that you make as part of this action hits a creature, you can use one of the following Blade Flourish options of your choice. You can use only one Blade Flourish option per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you join the College of Swords at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with medium armor and the {@item scimitar|phb}.
If you're proficient with a simple or martial melee weapon, you can use it as a spellcasting focus for your bard spells.

subclassFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: At 3rd level, you adopt a style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if something in the game lets you choose again.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your cantrips in place of one of those attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Master's Flourish
entries: Starting at 14th level, whenever you use a Blade Flourish option, you can reapply the effects of your bardic performance, or begin a new performance, without requiring a bonus action. Beginning a new performance expends another use, as normal.

subclassFeature.name: College of Whispers
entries: Most folk are happy to welcome a bard into their midst. Bards of the College of Whispers use this to their advantage. They appear to be like other bards, sharing news, singing songs, and telling tales to the audiences they gather. In truth, the College of Whispers teaches its students that they are wolves among sheep. These bards use their knowledge and magic to uncover secrets and turn them against others through extortion and threats.

Many other bards hate the College of Whispers, viewing it as a parasite that uses a bard's reputation to acquire wealth and power. For this reason, members of this college rarely reveal their true nature. They typically claim to follow some other college, or they keep their actual calling secret in order to infiltrate and exploit royal courts and other settings of power.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Blades
entries: When you join the College of Whispers at 3rd level, you gain the ability to make your weapon attacks magically toxic to a creature's mind.

When you hit a creature with a weapon attack while your Bardic Performance is active, you can  deal an extra amount of psychic damage to that target equal to two rolls of your performance die and they must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or be {condition frightened} of you until the start of your next turn. You can do so only once per round on your turn.
The psychic damage increases when you reach certain levels in this class, increasing to three rolls of your performance die at 5th level, four rolls at 10th level, and five rolls at 15th level.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Words of Terror
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to infuse innocent-seeming words with an insidious magic that can inspire terror.

If you speak to a humanoid alone for at least 1 minute, you can attempt to seed paranoia in its mind. At the end of the conversation, the target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or be {@condition frightened} of you or another creature of your choice. The target is {@condition frightened} in this way for 1 hour, until it is attacked or damaged, or until it witnesses its allies being attacked or damaged.
If the target succeeds on its saving throw, the target has no hint that you tried to frighten it.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Whispers
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to adopt a humanoid's persona. When a humanoid dies within 30 feet of you, you can magically capture its shadow using your reaction. You retain this shadow until you use it or you finish a long rest.

You can use the shadow as an action. When you do so, it vanishes, magically transforming into a disguise that appears on you. You now look like the dead person, but healthy and alive. This disguise lasts for 1 hour or until you end it as a bonus action.

While you're in the disguise, you gain access to all information that the humanoid would freely share with a casual acquaintance. Such information includes general details on its background and personal life, but doesn't include secrets. The information is enough that you can pass yourself off as the person by drawing on its memories.
Another creature can see through this disguise by succeeding on a Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check contested by your Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check. You gain a +5 bonus to your check.
Once you capture a shadow with this feature, you can't capture another one with it until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Lore
entries: At 14th level, you gain the ability to weave dark magic into your words and tap into a creature's deepest fears.

As an action, you magically whisper a phrase that only one creature of your choice within 30 feet of you can hear. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. It automatically succeeds if it doesn't share a language with you or if it can't hear you. On a successful saving throw, your whisper sounds like unintelligible mumbling and has no effect.

On a failed saving throw, the target is {@condition charmed} by you for the next 8 hours or until you or your allies attack it, damage it, or force it to make a saving throw. It interprets the whispers as a description of its most mortifying secret. You gain no knowledge of this secret, but the target is convinced you know it.

The {@condition charmed} creature obeys your commands for fear that you will reveal its secret. It won't risk its life for you or fight for you, unless it was already inclined to do so. It grants you favors and gifts it would offer to a close friend.
When the effect ends, the creature has no understanding of why it held you in such fear.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Defensive Flourish
entries: You swing your blade in defensive motions and deal extra damage to the target you hit. The damage equals one roll of your performance die. You also add the number rolled to your AC until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Mobile Flourish
entries: You swiftly flourish your weapon toward your enemy, causing them to move and deal extra damage to the target you hit. The damage equals one roll of your performance die. You can also push the target up to 5 feet away from you, plus a number of feet equal to the number you roll on that die. You can then immediately use your reaction to move up to your walking speed to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the target.

subclassFeature.name: Slashing Flourish
entries: You swing your weapon wide and deal extra damage to the target you hit and to any other creature of your choice that you can see within 5 feet of you. The damage equals one roll of your performance die.

subclassFeature.name: College Of The Elemental Dancer
entries: A true master of elements shifts between them, effortlessly and elegantly. As fluid with their movements as a flowing river, as hard to hit as a feather riding the wind, hits as hard as a flying rock, and as hot as flames when need be.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Dance
entries: Starting at 3rd level, when you begin a Bardic Performance, choose a tempo from air, earth, fire, or water. For the duration of the performance, you gain one of the following benefits depending on what you chose, and you can shift your chosen element as part of the same bonus action you use to reapply the effects of your bardic performance:

entries.caption: Elemental Dance Table
rows: Your movement speed is increased by 10 feet and you can hover up to a foot off the ground effortlessly. You can cast the {@spell cutting wind|TACS} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you.

Your body becomes tough as stone, you have resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage and you can cast the {@spell magic stone|XGE} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you.
You can cast the {@spell fire bolt} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you, and your weapon attacks deal an extra amount of fire damage equal to your performance die.

You can walk across the surface of water as you would solid ground, however you still fall through the water if you end your turn there. You can cast the {@spell water splash|TACS} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Tongue
entries: Also at 3rd level, your extensive knowledge on the elemental planes makes you an expert in conversing with said elementals. You know how to speak, read, and write Primordial. If you already have Primordial, you can instead choose a different language. In addition, you have advantage on Charisma ability checks made with elementals, provided you are not hostile toward them.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Performance
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can grant your elemental magic onto an ally while embracing it through your dance. When you begin a bardic performance, choose one of the affected creatures. Until the start of your next turn, that creature can add a performance die to the damage rolls of their attacks or spells. You can choose the same creature or a different one when you reapply the effects of your bardic performance. The bonus damage is dependent on your current chosen tempo:

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Dance Improvement
entries: Also at 6th level, you gain some additional effects while in your Elemental Dance. While under the effects of your Elemental Dance, you gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Charisma modifier provided you aren't wearing medium or heavy armor or using a shield. In addition, you gain the ability to cast certain spells while using your bard spell slots while under the effects of your Elemental Dance depending on your chosen tempo, which count as bard spells for you:

entries.caption: Elemental Dance Spells
rows: {@spell Rock Slide|TACS}, {@spell Boulder Bash|TACS}, {@spell Erupting Earth|XGE}

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Conductor
entries: Also at 14th level, you've learned to pinpoint weakness in even the most resistant foes. When you deal damage to a creature with a resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage, you can choose to ignore their resistance until the end of the current turn.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: College of Minstrel
entries: The College of Minstrel cannot be found on any map, nor is it defined to one location. No one place is defined as home to these bards, rather, they consider those they travel with their true home. The world is their home, and the people in it are mere extensions of their family. These bards protect their family as they would themselves and focus on healing. These bards also have a particular liking to poetry and songs, as it spreads joy to those who listen.

subclassFeature.name: Traveler's Song
entries: At 3rd level, while travelling or spending downtime you can play a song that keeps your allies focused and determined on their tasks.

Provided your allies can see or hear you during the task, they have advantage on any ability checks associated with the task. When you use this feature, you are assumed to be spending your own ability to partake in downtime activities or other tasks during travel, however you may still partake in certain tasks, such as performing at a tavern if the allies you are aiding are in said tavern, with approval by your DM.
In addition, one of those creatures may add a bonus to one of their rolls equal to one roll of your bardic inspiration die.

As an example, a Ranger who goes hunting for resources during downtime can have advantage on their Wisdom (Survival) ability check in addition to any other ability checks associated with hunting. Or, if you are traveling at a slow pace to stealth during your travel for safety, you and your allies can have advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks, provided they can see you. A wizard who is trying to sell a magic item in a tavern may still allow you to perform entertainment for the tavern and grant the benefits to the wizard.

subclassFeature.name: Minstrel's Melody
entries: Also at 3rd level, when a creature who is affected by your bardic performance would regain hit points by the effects of spell, they can roll a performance die and regain an additional amount of hit points equal to the number rolled.
A creature only gains this benefit if they have less than half of their maximum number of hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Shelter of The Travelers
entries: Starting at 6th level, you learn the {@spell Leomund's tiny hut} spell, which counts as a bard spell for you but doesn't count against your total number of known spells, and you can cast it once without expending a spell slot or requiring material components. When you cast the spell using this feature, the dome created covers a 20-foot radius instead, allowing more than 9 medium or smaller creatures to fit inside the radius, and you can enter and exit the hut as you please without ending the spell.

The hut itself, and creatures inside of the hut, are {@condition invisible} for the duration of the spell. As an action, you can allow the hut and the creatures inside of the hut to be seen, or you can use another action to hide the hut and the creatures inside.
You regain the ability to cast the spell in this way again when you finish a long rest, or if you expend a spell slot of 3rd level or higher to regain the ability to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Minstrel's Duet
entries: At 14th level, when you restore hit points to another creature using a spell of 1st-level or higher, you regain hit points equal to two rolls of your performance die.

subclassFeature.name: College of The Songblade
entries: In more ancient times, a group of elves created an order of bards which banded together when evil threatened the Arda Kingdom. These bards would empower their weapons with the power of their voice and songs, similar to another order of elf wizards. Unlike that order, this one was open with other races learning the secrets behind this power, opening up this bard college to all who wished to learn.
In modern days, this college is taught more for fun and sport. However, some of the eldest of elves are among those who founded the college, and they still know of its true purpose to thwart evil.

subclassFeature.name: Bond of The Songblade
entries: Starting at 3rd level when you choose this college, choose one weapon to become your Songblade from the following: dagger, longsword, rapier, or shortsword.
When you are holding a Songblade, you gain the following benefits:

items: You can use Charisma for the attack and damage rolls of a Songblade instead of Strength or Dexterity. In addition, it counts as a spellcasting focus for you and you can cast spells using somatic components even if both hands are occupied, so long as your Songblade is being held in one of them.
You gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Charisma modifier, provided you are not wearing medium or heavy armor.

entries: You can change which weapon your Songblade is when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Song of Love and War
entries: Also at 3rd level, when you cast a bard spell that requires a verbal component while your bardic performance is active, you can roll a performance die, adding the result to one of the damage or healing rolls.

Alternatively, when you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack using a Songblade while your bardic performance is active, you can expend one spell slot to deal psychic damage to the target, in addition to the weapon's damage. The extra damage is one roll of your performance die for a 1st-level spell slot, plus another performance die for each spell level higher than 1st, to a maximum of 3 performance dice.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Also at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your cantrips in place of one of those attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Resilience of The Songblade
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you begin your Bardic Performance, you can give each affected creature temporary hit points equal to your Bard level. When you reapply the effects of your bardic performance, they gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus, provided they did not have more temporary hit points remaining.

subclassFeature.name: Legacy of The Songblade
entries: Starting at 14th level, ancestors of the songblade college flow within you, granting you great harmonic power. While your bardic performance is active, you gain a bonus to damage rolls with your songblade and with your bard spells equal to one roll of your performance die.
In addition, you always gain a bonus to the damage rolls of your bard spells (including cantrips) equal to your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Berserker
entries: For some barbarians, rage is a means to an endthat end being violence. The Path of the Berserker is a path of untrammeled fury, slick with blood. As you enter the berserker's rage, you thrill in the chaos of battle, heedless of your own health or well-being.

subclassFeature.name: Frenzy
entries: Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, you can go into a frenzy when you rage. If you do so, for the duration of your rage you can make a single melee weapon attack as a bonus action on each of your turns after this one. When your rage ends, you suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

subclassFeature.name: Mindless Rage
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can't be {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} while raging. If you are {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} when you enter your rage, the effect is suspended for the duration of the rage.

subclassFeature.name: Intimidating Presence
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you can use your action to frighten someone with your menacing presence. When you do so, choose one creature that you can see within 30 feet of you. If the creature can see or hear you, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier) or be {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn. On subsequent turns, you can use your action to extend the duration of this effect on the {@condition frightened} creature until the end of your next turn. This effect ends if the creature ends its turn out of line of sight or more than 60 feet away from you.
If the creature succeeds on its saving throw, you can't use this feature on that creature again for 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Retaliation
entries: Starting at 14th level, when you take damage from a creature that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to make a melee weapon attack against that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Bear
entries: While raging, when you take damage, you reduce the total by an amount equal to your proficiency bonus. The spirit of the bear makes you tough enough to stand up to any punishment.

subclassFeature.name: Eagle
entries: While you're raging and aren't wearing heavy armor, other creatures have disadvantage on opportunity attack rolls against you, and you can use the {@action Dash} action as a bonus action on your turn. The spirit of the eagle makes you into a predator who can weave through the fray with ease.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Totem Warrior
entries: The Path of the Totem Warrior is a spiritual journey, as the barbarian accepts a spirit animal as guide, protector, and inspiration. In battle, your totem spirit fills you with supernatural might, adding magical fuel to your barbarian rage.
Most barbarian tribes consider a totem animal to be kin to a particular clan. In such cases, it is unusual for an individual to have more than one totem animal spirit, though exceptions exist.

subclassFeature.name: Wolf
entries: While you're raging, your friends have advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature within 5 feet of you that is hostile to you. The spirit of the wolf makes you a leader of hunters.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Seeker
entries: Yours is a path that seeks attunement with the natural world, giving you a kinship with beasts. At 3rd level when you adopt this path, you gain the ability to cast the {@spell beast sense} and {@spell speak with animals} spells, but only as rituals, as described in {@book chapter 10|PHB|10|rituals}.

subclassFeature.name: Totem Spirit
entries: At 3rd level, when you adopt this path, you choose a totem spirit and gain its feature. You must make or acquire a physical totem objectan amulet or similar adornmentthat incorporates fur or feathers, claws, teeth, or bones of the totem animal. At your option, you also gain minor physical attributes that are reminiscent of your totem spirit. For example, if you have a bear totem spirit, you might be unusually hairy and thick-skinned, or if your totem is the eagle, your eyes turn bright yellow.
Your totem animal might be an animal related to those listed here but more appropriate to your homeland. For example, you could choose a hawk or vulture in place of an eagle.

subclassFeature.name: Bear
entries: You gain the might of a bear. Your carrying capacity (including maximum load and maximum lift) is doubled, and you have advantage on Strength checks made to push, pull, lift, or break objects.

subclassFeature.name: Eagle
entries: You gain the eyesight of an eagle. You can see up to 1 mile away with no difficulty, able to discern even fine details as though looking at something no more than 100 feet away from you. Additionally, dim light doesn't impose disadvantage on your Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks.

subclassFeature.name: Wolf
entries: You gain the hunting sensibilities of a wolf. You can track other creatures while traveling at a fast pace, and you can move stealthily while traveling at a normal pace.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Beast
entries: At 6th level, you gain a magical benefit based on the totem animal of your choice. You can choose the same animal you selected at 3rd level or a different one.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Walker
entries: At 10th level, you can cast the {@spell commune with nature} spell, but only as a ritual. When you do so, a spiritual version of one of the animals you chose for Totem Spirit or Aspect of the Beast appears to you to convey the information you seek.

subclassFeature.name: Bear
entries: While you're raging, any creature within 5 feet of you that's hostile to you has disadvantage on attack rolls against targets other than you or another character with this feature. An enemy is immune to this effect if it can't see or hear you or if it can't be {@condition frightened}.

subclassFeature.name: Eagle
entries: While raging, you have a flying speed equal to your current walking speed. This benefit works only in short bursts; you fall if you end your turn in the air and nothing else is holding you aloft.

subclassFeature.name: Wolf
entries: While you're raging, you can use a bonus action on your turn to knock a Large or smaller creature {@condition prone} when you hit it with melee weapon attack.

subclassFeature.name: Totemic Attunement
entries: At 14th level, you gain a magical benefit based on a totem animal of your choice. You can choose the same animal you selected previously or a different one.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Beast
entries: Barbarians who walk the Path of the Beast draw their rage from a bestial spark burning within their souls. That beast bursts forth in the throes of rage, physically transforming the barbarian.
Such a barbarian might be inhabited by a primal spirit or be descended from shape-shifters. You can choose the origin of your feral might or determine it by rolling on the Origin of the Beast table.

entries.caption: Origin of the Beast
rows: One of your parents is a lycanthrope, and you've inherited some of their curse.
You are descended from an archdruid and inherited the ability to partially change shape.
A fey spirit gifted you with the ability to adopt different bestial aspects.
An ancient animal spirit dwells within you, allowing you to walk this path.

subclassFeature.name: Form of the Beast
entries: {@i 3rd-level Path of the Beast feature}

When you enter your rage, you can transform, revealing the bestial power within you. Until the rage ends, you manifest a natural weapon. It counts as a simple melee weapon for you, and you add your Strength modifier to the attack and damage rolls when you attack with it, as normal.
You choose the weapon's form each time you rage:

items.name: Bite
items.entry: Your mouth transforms into a bestial muzzle or great mandibles (your choice). It deals {@damage 1d8} piercing damage on a hit. Once on each of your turns when you damage a creature with this bite, you regain a number of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus, provided you have less than half your hit points when you hit.

items.name: Claws
items.entry: Each of your hands transforms into a claw, which you can use as a weapon if it's empty. It deals {@damage 1d6} slashing damage on a hit. Once on each of your turns when you attack with a claw using the {@action Attack} action, you can make one additional claw attack as part of the same action.

items.name: Tail
items.entry: You grow a lashing, spiny tail, which deals {@damage 1d8} piercing damage on a hit and has the reach property. If a creature you can see within 10 feet of you hits you with an attack roll, you can use your reaction to swipe your tail and roll a {@dice d8}, applying a bonus to your AC equal to the number rolled, potentially causing the attack to miss you.

subclassFeature.name: Bestial Soul
entries: {@i 6th-level Path of the Beast feature}
The feral power within you increases, causing the natural weapons of your Form of the Beast to count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

You can also alter your form to help you adapt to your surroundings. When you finish a short or long rest, choose one of the following benefits, which lasts until you finish your next short or long rest:

items: You gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed, and you can breathe underwater.
You gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed, and you can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.
When you jump, you can make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check and extend your jump by a number of feet equal to the check's total. You can make this special check only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Infectious Fury
entries: {@i 10th-level Path of the Beast feature}

When you hit a creature with your natural weapons while you are raging, the beast within you can curse your target with rabid fury. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus) or suffer one of the following effects (your choice):

items: The target must use its reaction to make a melee attack against another creature of your choice that you can see.
The target takes {@damage 2d12} psychic damage.

entries: You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Call the Hunt
entries: {@i 14th-level Path of the Beast feature}

The beast within you grows so powerful that you can spread its ferocity to others and gain resilience from them joining your hunt. When you enter your rage, you can choose a number of other willing creatures you can see within 30 feet of you equal to your Constitution modifier (minimum of one creature).

You gain 5 temporary hit points for each creature that accepts this feature. Until the rage ends, the chosen creatures can each use the following benefit once on each of their turns: when the creature hits a target with an attack roll and deals damage to it, the creature can roll a {@dice d6} and gain a bonus to the damage equal to the number rolled.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Path of Wild Magic
entries: Many places in the multiverse abound with beauty, intense emotion, and rampant magic; the Feywild, the Upper Planes, and other realms of supernatural power radiate with such forces and can profoundly influence people. As folk of deep feeling, barbarians are especially susceptible to these wild influences, with some barbarians being transformed by the magic. These magic-suffused barbarians walk the Path of Wild Magic. Elf, tiefling, aasimar, and genasi barbarians often seek this path, eager to manifest the otherworldly magic of their ancestors.

subclassFeature.name: Magic Awareness
entries: {@i 3rd-level Path of Wild Magic feature}

As an action, you can open your awareness to the presence of concentrated magic. Until the end of your next turn, you know the location of any spell or magic item within 60 feet of you that isn't behind total cover. When you sense a spell, you learn which school of magic it belongs to.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Surge
entries: {@i 3rd-level Path of Wild Magic feature}
The magical energy roiling inside you sometimes erupts from you. When you enter your rage, roll on the Wild Magic table to determine the magical effect produced.
If the effect requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

entries.caption: Wild Magic
rows: Shadowy tendrils lash around you. Each creature of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 1d12} necrotic damage. You also gain {@dice 1d12} temporary hit points.
You teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see. Until your rage ends, you can use this effect again on each of your turns as a bonus action.

An intangible spirit, which looks like a {@creature flumph} or a {@creature pixie} (your choice), appears within 5 feet of one creature of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you. At the end of the current turn, the spirit explodes, and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} force damage. Until your rage ends, you can use this effect again, summoning another spirit, on each of your turns as a bonus action.

Magic infuses one weapon of your choice that you are holding. Until your rage ends, the weapon's damage type changes to force, and it gains the light and thrown properties, with a normal range of 20 feet and a long range of 60 feet. If the weapon leaves your hand, the weapon reappears in your hand at the end of the current turn.
Whenever a creature hits you with an attack roll before your rage ends, that creature takes {@damage 1d6} force damage, as magic lashes out in retribution.
Until your rage ends, you are surrounded by multi colored, protective lights; you gain a +1 bonus to AC, and while within 10 feet of you, your allies gain the same bonus.
Flowers and vines temporarily grow around you. Until your rage ends, the ground within 15 feet of you is {@quickref difficult terrain|TACS|3} for your enemies.

A bolt of light shoots from your chest. Another creature of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} radiant damage and be {@condition blinded} until the start of your next turn. Until your rage ends, you can use this effect again on each of your turns as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Bolstering Magic
entries: {@i 6th-level Path of Wild Magic feature}

You can harness your wild magic to bolster yourself or a companion. As an action, you can touch one creature (which can be yourself) and confer one of the following benefits of your choice to that creature:

items: For 10 minutes, the creature can roll a {@dice d3} whenever making an attack roll or an ability check and add the number rolled to the {@dice d20} roll.

Roll a {@dice d3}. The creature regains one expended spell slot, the level of which equals the number rolled or lower (the creature's choice). Once a creature receives this benefit, that creature can't receive it again until after a long rest.

entries: You can take this action a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Unpredictable Resistance
entries: {@i 6th-level Path of Wild Magic feature}
The following damage resistances are added to the list you can choose from your barbaric resistance feature: force and psychic.

subclassFeature.name: Unstable Backlash
entries: {@i 10th-level Path of Wild Magic feature}

When you are imperiled during your rage, the magic within you can lash out; immediately after you take damage or fail a saving throw while raging, you can use your reaction to roll on the Wild Magic table and immediately produce the effect rolled. This effect replaces your current Wild Magic effect.

subclassFeature.name: Controlled Surge
entries: {@i 14th-level Path of Wild Magic feature}

Whenever you roll on the Wild Magic table, you can roll the die twice and choose which of the two effects to unleash. If you roll the same number on both dice, you can ignore the number and choose any effect on the table.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Ancestral Guardian
entries: Some barbarians hail from cultures that revere their ancestors. These tribes teach that the warriors of the past linger in the world as mighty spirits, who can guide and protect the living. When a barbarian who follows this path rages, the barbarian contacts the spirit world and calls on these guardian spirits for aid.

Barbarians who draw on their ancestral guardians can better fight to protect their tribes and their allies. In order to cement ties to their ancestral guardians, barbarians who follow this path cover themselves in elaborate tattoos that celebrate their ancestors' deeds. These tattoos tell sagas of victories against terrible monsters and other fearsome rivals.

subclassFeature.name: Ancestral Protectors
entries: Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, spectral warriors appear when you enter your rage. While you're raging, the first creature you hit with an attack on your turn becomes the target of the warriors, which hinder its attacks. Until the start of your next turn, that target has disadvantage on any attack roll that isn't against you, and when the target hits a creature other than you with an attack, that creature has resistance to the damage dealt by the attack. The effect on the target ends early if your rage ends.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Shield
entries: Beginning at 6th level, the guardian spirits that aid you can provide supernatural protection to those you defend. If you are raging and another creature you can see within 30 feet of you takes damage, you can use your reaction to reduce that damage by {@dice 2d6}.
When you reach certain levels in this class, you can reduce the damage by more: by {@dice 3d6} at 10th level and by {@dice 4d6} at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Spiritual Resistance
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain resistance to force damage while you are raging, as your ancestors from beyond the veil protect your soul.

subclassFeature.name: Consult the Spirits
entries: At 10th level, you gain the ability to consult with your ancestral spirits. When you do so, you cast the {@spell augury} or {@spell clairvoyance} spell, without using a spell slot or material components. Rather than creating a spherical sensor, this use of {@spell clairvoyance} invisibly summons one of your ancestral spirits to the chosen location. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.
After you cast either spell in this way, you can't use this feature again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Vengeful Ancestors
entries: At 14th level, your ancestral spirits grow powerful enough to retaliate. When you use your Spirit Shield to reduce the damage of an attack, the attacker takes an amount of force damage equal to the damage that your Spirit Shield prevents.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Storm Herald
entries: All barbarians harbor a fury within. Their rage grants them superior strength, durability, and speed. Barbarians who follow the Path of the Storm Herald learn to transform that rage into a mantle of primal magic, which swirls around them. When in a fury, a barbarian of this path taps into the forces of nature to create powerful magical effects.

Storm heralds are typically elite champions who train alongside druids, rangers, and others sworn to protect nature. Other storm heralds hone their craft in lodges in regions wracked by storms, in the frozen reaches at the world's end, or deep in the hottest deserts.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Aura
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you emanate a stormy, magical aura while you rage. The aura extends 10 feet from you in every direction, but not through total cover.

Your aura has an effect that activates when you enter your rage, and you can activate the effect again on each of your turns as a bonus action. Choose desert, sea, or tundra. Your aura's effect depends on that chosen environment, as detailed below. You can change your environment choice whenever you gain a level in this class.
If your aura's effects require a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Soul
entries: At 6th level, the storm grants you benefits even when your aura isn't active. The benefits are based on the environment you chose for your Storm Aura.

subclassFeature.name: Shielding Storm
entries: At 10th level, you learn to use your mastery of the storm to protect others. Each creature of your choice has the damage resistance you gained from the Storm Soul feature while the creature is in your Storm Aura.

subclassFeature.name: Raging Storm
entries: At 14th level, the power of the storm you channel grows mightier, lashing out at your foes. The effect is based on the environment you chose for your Storm Aura.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Zealot
entries: Some deities inspire their followers to pitch themselves into a ferocious battle fury. These barbarians are zealotswarriors who channel their rage into powerful displays of divine power.

A variety of gods across the worlds of D&D inspire their followers to embrace this path. Tempus from the Forgotten Realms and Hextor and Erythnul of Greyhawk are all prime examples. In general, the gods who inspire zealots are deities of combat, destruction, and violence. Not all are evil, but few are good.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Fury
entries: Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, you can channel divine fury into your weapon strikes. While you're raging, the first creature you hit on each of your turns with a weapon attack takes extra damage equal to {@dice 1d6} + half your barbarian level. The extra damage is necrotic or radiant; you choose the type of damage when you gain this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Warrior of the Gods
entries: At 3rd level, your soul is marked for endless battle. If a spell, such as {@spell raise dead}, has the sole effect of restoring you to life (but not undeath), the caster doesn't need material components to cast the spell on you.

subclassFeature.name: Fanatical Focus
entries: Starting at 6th level, the divine power that fuels your rage can protect you. If you fail a saving throw while you're raging, you can reroll it, and you must use the new roll. You can use this ability only once per rage.

subclassFeature.name: Zealous Resistance
entries: Starting at 6th level, the following damage resistances are added to the list you can choose from your barbaric resistance feature: radiant and necrotic.

subclassFeature.name: Zealous Presence
entries: At 10th level, you learn to channel divine power to inspire zealotry in others. As a bonus action, you unleash a battle cry infused with divine energy. Up to ten other creatures of your choice within 60 feet of you that can hear you gain advantage on attack rolls and saving throws until the start of your next turn.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Rage beyond Death
entries: Beginning at 14th level, the divine power that fuels your rage allows you to shrug off fatal blows.

While you're raging, having 0 hit points doesn't knock you {@condition unconscious}. You still must make death saving throws, and you suffer the normal effects of taking damage while at 0 hit points. However, if you would die due to failing death saving throws, you don't die until your rage ends, and you die then only if you still have 0 hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Elk
entries: While you're raging and aren't wearing heavy armor, your walking speed increases by 15 feet. The spirit of the elk makes you extraordinarily swift.

subclassFeature.name: Tiger
entries: While raging, you can add 10 feet to your long jump distance and 3 feet to your high jump distance. The spirit of the tiger empowers your leaps.

subclassFeature.name: Elk
entries: Whether mounted or on foot, your travel pace is doubled, as is the travel pace of up to ten companions while they're within 60 feet of you and you're not {@condition incapacitated}. The elk spirit helps you roam far and fast.

subclassFeature.name: Tiger
entries: You gain proficiency in two skills from the following list: {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Acrobatics}, {@skill Stealth}, and {@skill Survival}. The cat spirit hones your survival instincts.

subclassFeature.name: Elk
entries: While raging, you can use a bonus action during your move to pass through the space of a Large or smaller creature. That creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC 8 + your Strength bonus + your proficiency bonus) or be knocked {@condition prone} and take bludgeoning damage equal to {@dice 1d12} + your Strength modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Tiger
entries: While you're raging, if you move at least 20 feet in a straight line toward a Large or smaller target right before making a melee weapon attack against it, you can use a bonus action to make an additional melee weapon attack against it.

subclassFeature.name: Desert
entries: When this effect is activated, all other creatures in your aura take {@dice 1d4} fire damage each. The damage increases when you reach certain levels in this class, increasing to {@dice 2d4} at 5th level, {@dice 3d4} at 11th level, and {@dice 4d4} at 17th level. In addition, when a creature takes this damage, they have disadvantage on their next attack roll until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Sea
entries: When this effect is activated, you can choose one other creature you can see in your aura. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw. The target takes {@dice 1d10} lightning damage and cannot take reactions until the start of your next turn on a failed save, or half as much damage and and suffers no additional effects on a successful one. The damage increases when you reach certain levels in this class, increasing to {@dice 2d10} at 5th level, {@dice 3d10} at 11th level, and {@dice 4d10} at 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Tundra
entries: When this effect is activated, each creature of your choice in your aura gains 4 temporary hit points, as icy spirits inure it to suffering. The temporary hit points increase when you reach certain levels in this class, increasing to 6 at 5th level, 8 at 11th level, and 10 at 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Desert
entries: You gain resistance to fire damage, and you don't suffer the effects of extreme heat, as described in the Dungeon Master's Guide. Moreover, as an action, you can touch a flammable object that isn't being worn or carried by anyone else and set it on fire.

subclassFeature.name: Sea
entries: You gain resistance to lightning damage, and you can breathe underwater. You also gain a swimming speed of 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Tundra
entries: You gain resistance to cold damage, and you don't suffer the effects of extreme cold, as described in the Dungeon Master's Guide. Moreover, as an action, you can touch water and turn a 5-foot cube of it into ice, which melts after 1 minute. This action fails if a creature is in the cube.

subclassFeature.name: Desert
entries: Immediately after a creature in your aura hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to force that creature to make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes fire damage equal to half your barbarian level.

subclassFeature.name: Sea
entries: When you hit a creature in your aura with an attack, you can use your reaction to force that creature to make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is knocked {@condition prone}, as if struck by a wave.

subclassFeature.name: Tundra
entries: Whenever the effect of your Storm Aura is activated, you can choose one creature you can see in the aura. That creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw, or its speed is reduced to 0 until the start of your next turn, as magical frost covers it.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Dragon
entries: Some warriors are born in the depths of a dragon's lair where they absorb the lingering magic in the area, allowing them to channel it into their burning rage.

Most barbarian tribes who worship dragonkind usually revere them as gods for their unmatched strength and frightening auras. Barbarians who can harness their dragonkin's powers are often regarded as the strongest of their tribes.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Ancestor
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to speak, read, and write Draconic or one other language of your choice. In addition, you've grown up around dragons, inheriting some of their magic. Choose chromatic, gem, or metallic. You can then choose one damage type that is associated with your chosen draconic ancestor. The damage type you choose is used by features you gain later.

entries.caption: Draconic Ancestor
rows: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison

entries: If a feature from this subclass requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Fury of The Dragon
entries: At 3rd level, you can channel draconic energy into your weapon strikes. While you're raging, the first creature you hit on each of your turns with a weapon attack takes extra damage equal to {@dice 1d6}. The extra damage is the damage type associated with your draconic ancestor.
The extra damage increases to {@dice 2d6} at 9th level and {@dice 3d6} at 16th level.

subclassFeature.name: Rage of The Dragon
entries: Also at 3rd level, when you enter your rage your body becomes riddled with dragon scales as you undergo a draconic transformation. While raging, you gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Rage Damage Bonus, provided you are not wearing any armor.
In addition, you gain resistance to the damage type associated with your draconic ancestor while raging.

subclassFeature.name: Breath of The Raging Dragon
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can channel the draconic energies within and exhale it into a powerful magical burst. While raging when you take the Attack action on your turn, you can replace one of the attacks with an exhalation of draconic energy in either a 20-foot cone or a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide (your choice). Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw. They take {@dice 2d10} damage of the type associated with your draconic ancestor on a failed save, or half as much on a success.
At 13th level, the damage of this feature increases to {@dice 3d10} and {@dice 4d10} at 17th level.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. While you have no uses available, you can expend a use of your rage to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Wings of The Raging Dragon
entries: Starting at 10th level, when you enter your rage, or as a bonus action on subsequent turns while raging, you can furl or unfurl dragon-like wings from your body. While unfurled, your wings grant you a flying speed equal to your walking speed. If you already had a flying speed, it is increased by an amount equal to half your walking speed.

If you are wearing armor, to unfurl your wings your armor must be made to accommodate them. When your rage ends, your wings instantly become furled, causing you to fall if you were still flying when they furl.

subclassFeature.name: Frightening Rage
entries: At 14th level, when you enter your rage you create an aura of frightening power. At the start of each of their turns, every creature that can see or hear you within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw or become {condition frightened} of you for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a successful save.
A creature that succeeds their saving throw is immune to this aura's effect for 1 hour.

optionalfeature.name: Starlight Rod

item: a small or tiny object that can fit in the hand of a humanoid or similarly shaped creature

entries: The object has dormant magical energy which can be used to light an area around it. As a bonus action, the magic within can be called upon causing it to glow and shed bright light for a range of 30 feet in every direction and dim light for an additional 30 feet. The magic can also be dismissed as a bonus action.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 10 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Sound Recorder
entries: The object has buttons attached to it that can magically record sounds nearby it. Pressing a button requires a free item interaction. There are three buttons on the device, one to toggle a recording, one to toggle playback of a recording tape, and one to export a recording to a free tape.

The sound recorder can record sounds from up to 30 feet away, but anything further than 10 feet of the recorder sounds muffled and unclear, requiring a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check to make out clearly enough to understand words. A creature being recorded can try to suppress or muffle their words to become inaudible to the recorder, requiring a DC 15 Stealth check to speak quietly enough. The DC becomes 10 if the creature is more than 10 feet away from the recorder. The recorder can be used to record up to 1 hour of sound. Pressing the record button again after ending a recording overwrites the previous sound recording.

When applying this Tinker Mod, a slot is created on the recorder to insert blank tapes. The recorder also comes with 5 blank tapes which can store these sound recordings, but by knowing this Tinker Mod allows an Artificer to create more blank tapes with 5 gp worth of materials and 10 minutes of work. Should this Tinker Mod be lost, the 5 tapes created with it are lost. To store a recording on a tape, insert the tape into the slot created when applying the Tinker Mod, and press the button to export a recording. The tapes are small enough to fit within the palm of your hand, or smaller, but large enough to be seen to an untrained eye.
An artificer who applied this Tinker Mod on an object can use an action to activate one of its functions, as long as they are within 600 feet of the recorder.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 100 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Portable Cover

item: a small object no more than slightly larger than a chest, proficiency with Smith's Tools

entries: There is a single button which toggles the object's ability to become a form of modular cover. It has two forms, which a creature can cause it to shift by pressing the button as a bonus action. Its regular form takes the shape of a small box about 4 inches in width, height, and length. Its
cover
form takes the shape of a small plane, the dimensions of which are large enough to serve as half cover.

This object is modular while in its cover form, allowing other objects with this tinker mod to combine, forming three-fourths cover with two of them combined and full cover with three combined. Combining them uses the same bonus action to change its form, or bonus action on a subsequent turn. Detaching them is also a bonus action.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 50 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Alchemical Explosive

item: a bottle, flask, vial, or similarly sized object that can contain liquid, proficiency with Alchemist Supplies

entries: An unstable alchemical concoction with explosive properties. Inside the concoction is a single chemical which can stir the solution, causing it to explode, wrapped in a special protective sleeve. The sleeve, when exposed to air or gas, cracks and releases the chemical.
When an artificer applies this Tinker Mod, they choose what type of damage the explosive deals from acid, cold, fire, or poison.

As an action, a creature can throw the explosive up to 20 feet away, which shatters the container on impact. When aiming at a creature, they make an improvised ranged attack using Dexterity, which deals 1 piercing damage on hit. Once exposed to the air or gas, the alchemical solution explodes in a 10-foot radius, dealing {@dice 2d6} damage of the chosen type to creatures who fail a Dexterity saving throw, or half as much on a success.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 20 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Explosive Ammunition
entries: A piece of ammunition, laced with a solvent that explodes in response to a sharp and powerful impact. The solvent can coat the tip of the ammunition or be injected with it. When an artificer applies this Tinker Mod, they choose what type of damage the explosive deals from acid, cold, fire, or poison.
When a creature hits with a ranged attack using this special ammunition, it deals {@dice 1d6} of the chosen damage in addition to its normal effects.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 10 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

item: a piece of ammunition, proficiency with Smith's Tools

optionalfeature.name: External Defenses

item: a tiny object that is no larger than half the size of a shield, proficiency with Smith's Tools

entries: An object with this Tinker Mod can be placed onto a shield or suit of armor, enhancing its defenses with magic. The wearer receives a +1 bonus to their AC, which lasts until they take any amount of damage, after which the bonus is suppressed until the start of their next turn. Only one object with this Tinker Mod can be placed onto a shield or suit of armor at a time.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 100 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Culinary Masterpiece

item: A tiny or small pot, pan, or other utensil used to cook with, proficiency with Cook's Utensils

entries: An object with this Tinker Mod can be used to create amazingly tasting food, even with the poorest ingredients. When cooking with this object, you have a magical +1 bonus to ability checks made when using Cook's Utensils. In addition, when creatures eat food cooked with this object during a short or long rest, or during 10 minutes of respite, they gain 2d6 temporary hit points.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 20 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Holo-Recorder

item: a tiny or small object

entries: An object with this Tinker Mod is given a small screen which can capture and display moving 3-Dimensional images. It also comes with a disc slot which allows it to record and store these recreated scenes. 5 discs are magically created along with the modified object.

To capture a scene, simply hold up the device and press a button to begin capturing. The device magically scans the area within a 120-foot cone, capturing complex data allowing it to process and simulate a 3-Dimensional recreation of the scene, which can be rotated 360 degrees in any direction with perfect accuracy. Pressing the same button ends the capture early. It does not capture anything being blocked by walls or invisible creatures. Pressing the button after that begins capturing again, but removes the previously captured images. You can capture up to an hour of footage before the capturing ends early. You can display these scenes by placing the object with the lens facing upward and pressing a second button which can playback a previously recorded scene, either from a disc or the most recent capturing.

A creature can interact with the display by touching it, using their hands to rotate, zoom, or adjust the viewing of the scene. Making such changes or interactions to the image requires an action. The scene can also be adjusted to playback in various speeds: realtime, slowed, or fast. Realtime is an accurate depiction of the flow of time within the scene, slowed is anywhere from twice as long to up to 10 times as long (you choose the rate), and fast can be half as much time to as much as 10 times speed (you choose the rate).

A scene can be exported to a disc by pressing a third button, which stores it onto a blank disc that's been inserted into the special slot. If this Tinker Mod is lost, the 5 discs created with it are also lost. By knowing this Tinker Mod allows an Artificer to create more blank discs with 5 gp worth of materials and 10 minutes of work.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 200 gp worth of materials and 4 hours of work.

optionalfeature.name: Hovering Item
entries: A button appears on the object, which allows it to hover up to 5 feet off the ground and orbit around the creature who pressed the button while it isn't being worn or carried. If the button was pressed but not by a creature, it simply hovers 5 feet off the ground. Pressing the button again makes it harmlessly float down.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 50 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Boomerang

item: a tiny object which can be carried in one hand, proficiency with Smith's Tools

entries: An object with this Tinker Mod is treated as a simple ranged weapon, which has the finesse, light, and thrown properties and has a range of 20/60 ft. On hit, it deals 1d4 bludgeoning or piercing damage (chosen on application of Tinker Mod). Hit or miss, the object flies back into the attacker's hand.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 10 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Holy Grenade

item: proficiency in Religion, a flask or vial of holy water, proficiency with Alchemist Supplies

entries: A solution of chemicals and holy water which creates a burst of a sparkling gas that is deadly to fiends and undead. A creature can throw this grenade as an action up to 20 feet, on impact it releases a potent golden gas which deals {@dice 4d6} radiant damage to fiends and undead in a 10-foot radius of the object on a failed Constitution saving throw, or half as much on a success. When aiming at a creature, they make an improvised ranged attack using Dexterity, which deals 1 piercing damage and {@dice 2d6} radiant damage on fiends or undead on hit.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 30 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Night Vision Lenses

item: the Darkvision spell, a pair of glass lenses

entries: A set of lenses which can be set into glasses or goggles that can be worn by a humanoid, they can even be applied as a form of contact lenses. A creature wearing these lenses can see in darkness as they do dim light out to a range of 30 feet, and in dim light as they do in bright light out to the same range. A creature can not discern color with these lenses and see in only shades of green.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 30 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Live Holo-Recorder

item: a small or larger object, Holo-Recorder

entries: An object with this Tinker Mod can be linked to a Holo-Recorder to provide a live feed of whatever the screen is being pointed at. A similar screen is on this object, except that it mirrors what the holo-recorder sees. This image cannot be rotated or modified in any way until after the recording is saved to a disc and played back. To link this object with a holo-recorder, you touch both objects and spend an action focusing on both objects.
All linked objects must be on the same plane of existence, or the link between them breaks.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 100 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Live Recorder

item: a small or larger object, Sound Recorder Tinker Mod

entries: An object with this Tinker Mod can be used to record a live feed from an object with the Sound Recorder Tinker Mod. This recording is separate from the recording made on the sound recorder itself. The live recorder has its own slot to put blank tapes in, which you can record up to an hour of live feed. To record and save it onto a tape, there's a button you can press to start recording, which it automatically saves onto a blank tape provided it is in the slot.

To link this object with a sound recorder, you touch both objects and spend an action focusing on both objects. Multiple sound recorders can be linked to one live recorder, a button appears for each one to isolate or merge different live feeds. If two or more sound recorders are within the clear sound range, and sound can be heard from them. feedback is generated which deals 1 point of thunder damage to each creature within 10 feet of the live recorder who is not {@condition deafened}.

A set of headphones comes with the Tinker Mod, which can be worn to isolate the live feed to the wearer by plugging it directly into the device, and is compatible with the sound recorder and functions the same way (with perhaps a modification made to the sound recorder). An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can create a permanent set with 10 gp worth of materials. If this tinker mod is lost, so is the set of headphones created with it.
All linked objects must be on the same plane of existence, or the link between them breaks.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 100 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Sound Extender

item: a small or larger object, Sound Recorder Tinker Mod

entries: You can attach an object with this Tinker Mod to an object with the Sound Recorder Tinker Mod. Doing so doubles the audible range and sound within 30 feet is perfectly clear. The DC for a creature to suppress their voice from recorded sound becomes 20 from any range.
All linked objects must be on the same plane of existence, or the link between them breaks.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 100 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Personal Recorder

item: a tiny object that can be worn or carried, Live Recorder

entries: An object with this Tinker Mod can be attached to your clothing or worn near your face. It functions similarly to a sound recorder, except it only records the wearer's voice and other sounds originating from them, such as music. It can be connected to a live recorder using the same method listed in that mod.
All linked objects must be on the same plane of existence, or the link between them breaks.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 50 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Cantrip Focus

item: a tiny or small object that can be worn or carried

entries: The object with this Tinker Mod becomes a special focus for casting cantrips. When applying this Tinker Mod, an artificer chooses one of their known cantrips or a willing creature can offer one of theirs if they participate in the modification process in some way. The object becomes the spellcasting focus for that cantrip and it can be cast from it, even if the user cannot normally cast spells. If the user has a spellcasting or pact magic trait, it uses theirs, otherwise the spellcasting ability is Intelligence.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 100 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Spring Boots

item: a pair of boots that can be worn, proficiency with Cobbler's Tools

entries: Boots with this Tinker Mod can allow the wearer to use their Intelligence when determining how far they can jump, as opposed to their Strength. In addition, as a bonus action a creature can enhance their springy leaps with magic, doubling their jump distance until the start of their next turn.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 100 gp worth of materials and 1 hour of work.

optionalfeature.name: Alchemical Oils

item: a flask of oil, proficiency with Alchemist Supplies

entries: A flask of oil with this Tinker Mod becomes enhanced by potent chemicals, granting the oil elemental properties. When you apply this Tinker Mod, choose from acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison. This oil has one use. As a bonus action, a creature can coat a melee weapon with this oil, allowing it to deal an additional 2d6 of the chosen damage on hit. The oil retains its potency when coated on a weapon for 1 minute, or until the weapon has hit a target three times.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 200 gp worth of materials and 2 hours of work.

optionalfeature.name: Protective Oils

item: a flask of oil, proficiency with Alchemist Supplies

entries: A flask of oil with this Tinker Mod becomes enhanced by potent chemicals, allowing it to create a thin protective layer over outfits and armor. This oil has one use. As a bonus action, a creature can apply this oil, reducing damage they take by 2d6. Once this property has been used three times, or 1 minute has passed, a creature no longer benefits from it.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 200 gp worth of materials and 2 hours of work.

optionalfeature.name: Playback Hub

item: a medium or larger object, sound recorder and holo-recorder Tinker Mod

entries: An object with this Tinker Mod can be used to playback sound, moving images, or both from the sound recorder, live recorder, and the hologram projector. It can be connected to any number of objects with the listed Tinker Mods, by touching each object and spending an action to connect them. A playback hub has a screen on it which displays the scene, but with the option to view it in a 2-dimensional or 3-dimensional viewpoint.

A playback hub has a slot to insert a tape with a recording on it and a disc with a scene on it. There is a button to toggle playback for both and for isolated playback of one of the two. There is also an extra disc slot, which can be used to insert a blank disc and export both sound and a scene onto it by pressing a button. It takes 1 minute to export properly.
If connected to a live recorder, a live holo-recorder, or both, you can have a live playback of either one or both at the same time.
All linked objects must be on the same plane of existence, or the link between them breaks.
An artificer with the knowledge of this Tinker Mod can modify an object to have this mod permanently by spending 1000 gp worth of materials and 8 hours of work.

optionalfeature.name: Armor of Magical Strength

item: A suit of armor (requires attunement)

entries: This armor has 6 charges. The wearer can expend the armor's charges in the following ways:

items: When the wearer makes a Strength check or a Strength saving throw, it can expend 1 charge to add a bonus to the roll equal to its Intelligence modifier.
If the creature would be knocked {@condition prone}, it can use its reaction to expend 1 charge to avoid being knocked prone.

entries: The armor regains {@dice 1d6} expended charges daily at dawn.

optionalfeature.name: Boots of the Winding Path

item: A pair of boots

entries: While wearing these boots, a creature can teleport up to 15 feet as a bonus action to an unoccupied space the creature can see. The creature must have occupied that space at some point during the current turn.

optionalfeature.name: Catapulter

item: A sling, 50ft of rope, or any crossbow

entries: While holding this device, a creature can double the range of thrown weapons and the range of any object that can be thrown by loading the object into the device. Loading it requires a free item interaction, which can be done in tandem with movement or actions.

optionalfeature.name: Enhanced Arcane Focus

item: An object that can be used as a spellcasting focus (requires attunement)

entries: While holding this item, a creature gains a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls. In addition, the creature ignores half cover when making a spell attack.
The bonus increases to +2 when you reach 10th level in this class.

optionalfeature.name: Enhanced Defense

item: A suit of armor or a shield
